reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1 Captains Log:
I have put together a small crew and we finally embark on our inter-stellar journey. We came underattack by many security drones who engaged us on site. They were easy prey and yielded much needed scrap that eventually sold. The crew seemed pleased. No troubles here

Day 5 Cpatians Log:
We found a planet. It appears to be a molten planet inhabited by strange Lava creatures. I gave the order to exterminate them. No creature like that can ever be useful, or friendly. Of course, I would have sent a larger exploration force to the planet had I known there were lifeforms on the surface, but my science officer a man by the name of SCIBOT was more interested in the strange alien pumpkin that resides on the bridge than any of his duties. As soon as we dock at the nearest station He Fired.
As for my Engineering officer he seems more focused exploring the vast expanse of the galaxy, or finding enemies to kill than manning his post twice now we nearly had to jettison the core due to overheating. And for the life of me i dont understand how he cant keep our engines online in a fight.
My Tactical Officer doesnt want to use her missles and is often times facing the worng direction when we come into a fight. I swear this cannot be the same person i hired 4 days ago. Had i the techincal know how to operate the main cannon i would. I am also beginng to suspect her of an Atrium Healing pad addicition. Perhaps i could replace her and make her the new science officer she cant be any worse than SCIBOT.
My pilot has to be the only truely competant member of my crew he's always at his post. He's always vigilant and always ready to react to any situation.

Day 5 Chief Engineers Log:
How did i get here? Everything was perfect when I first signed up for this gig, but now its all gone to hell. That Science Officer is worthless. I mean sure he knows his craft, but the guy is more interested in those damend pumpkins all over the ship thna he is with anything else. I'm pretty sure the Captain is going to shoot him pretty soon. Oh and the Captain is a ♥♥♥♥♥. If you push the ship too hard your going to risk a core meltdown. But noooo, every fight he has to have all systems at max power and the ship at full burn FLank speed. Any first year officer would know that with running a ship like that you're going to run a core overheat. Our weapons officer is kinda flakey too I think she just fires the main cannon to watch the pretty light more times than not I jumped on a turret just to kill the enemy. Anyway I should probably get back to fixing the engines. I almost forgot about them.

Day 5 Tactical Officers Log:
Wow I've never been on a real spaceship before. Everyone here is super cool and really nice. I mean the Captian can get yelly sometimes, but he means the best. We must be like the best at our jobs because we keep getting in fights and winning. I get to fire the big shiny gun. It reminds me of the 4th of July. Anyway I'll see you later mom.

Day 5 Science Officers Log:
Pumpkin. Space Pumpkin. Space Pumkin with sparkles? Space SParkle Pumpkin. Tell me your secrets sPace Sparkle Pumpkin.

Day 5 Pilots Log:
Were all going to die.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game for 6 Hours Straight immediately after purchasing.

>First Crew
>Be Engineer
>Say Hello
>Get Kicked

>Second Crew
>Be Engineer
>People seem nice
>Start adjusting things slightly
>Someone Warps
>I get blamed
>We get attacked
>Something gets set on fire
>We blow up

>Same Crew
>Someone is engineer
>Pilot is only space left
>Choose Pilot
>Align Ship
>Warp
>We are attacked
>Enemy is below us
>Not sure what to do
>Someone tells me to get under enemy
>I do
>We destroy it
>Get told Good Job
>This is fun
>Someone gets kicked
>Glad it's not me

>Many warps and fights later
>Told I am really good
>Asked if played this or games like it before
>'Not really'
>Get told I'm good again, feel proud

>6 Hours later we have died a couple times
>Completed a lot of missions
>Had quite a few different people join me and the captain
>Eventually we part ways
>So many memories
>So Sad
>Many Tears

11/10 Best Damn Game Ever.

In seriousness I had so much fun, I was a fan of FTL but not a hardcore fan but this game brings the feeling of being a vital part of a crew, every action you take could save everything or destroy everything. And while you're manning the pilot seat or adjusting sliders you know that there are other people also trying their best to keep the ship alive. At the moment, to my knowledge, you don't fight other players but if that could be an addition to the game It would make it 100x better!

Though lacking of content, performing tasks is so satisfying that I don't even pay much attention to everything else. If you like FTL, Coop games or Space Exploration games then BUY THIS GAME NOW. You will not regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction
Think FTL but in first person, with other people!

Pulsar: Lost Colony is a space combat/exploration game that recently entered early access. In Pulsar you take control of a spacecraft with a crew of five humans/bots and with this spacecraft you explore a huge galaxy filled with danger. As you take on, and hopefully destroy, enemies you’ll be awarded with credits which can be spent on upgrades for your craft to make it far more effective. Pulsar also allows you to send away teams onto planets to search for items, lifeforms and everything in-between.

I won’t explain what the different classes in the game do but I will talk about them in my review so if you wish to know more about the classes look at the Overview in the Manual: http://www.pulsarthegame.com/manual/

Presentation
First up, the overall appearance of the game; it’s by no means the best looking game going but the graphical style definitely fits with the game, particularly for the ships, so I can’t fault it here. The ships themselves look absolutely fantastic, both inside and out. The character models and a few of the textures on the planets are a leaning towards the not so great side of things but this can be forgiven since you don’t spend too much time looking at either since most of the time in game is spent keeping the ship working during combat. The main menu is simple and gets the job done, not much to say here. Apart from the chat window there’s not really a UI in the game but the space craft’s ship displays are the equivalent here. The displays are what you spend most of your time looking at if you play as an engineer or a scientist but they’re also important to the other classes. They’re all done very well as they’re simple and easy to use. The one for engineering is particularly good as it’s just sliders and toggle buttons and engineers need to change things quickly.

Gameplay
Pulsar lets you choose from one of five (currently) ships, each with its own stats, advantages, disadvantages etc. Once you’ve selected your ship and you’ve assembled your crew you can either take and complete missions or you can just go off exploring in the randomly generated galaxy. I spent most of my time just travelling around the galaxy randomly, i.e. without trying to complete missions, and it felt rather similar to FTL. The Captain of your ship sets a course for you and then the pilot (human or AI) has to line the ship up with the system you’re travelling to so the engineer can trigger a jump to that system.

Arriving in a system can lead to any of the following situations: combat with one or more basic enemies, combat with a ‘boss’, the discovery of a trading post/repair depot, the discovery of a planet which can be explored or the discovery of empty space. More often than not you find yourself in the first situation so I’ll go ahead and explain how combat works. Depending on which ship you choose you’ll have a number of different weapons available to you, all of which can either be controlled by different players or can be controlled by the WeaponBot. Your weapons can only be used a certain number of times before needing to recharge, how long this recharge time is depends on what weapon it is and how much power you’ve diverted to weaponry. The recharge times are generally rather long and this is my first major issue with the gameplay since it makes combat feel rather slow whereas, in my opinion, it should be much faster paced. Enemy ships can also be boarded once a certain amount of their shields have gone down, boarding a ship allows you to kill its crew and then take over the ship or just destroy its systems.

AI
Pulsar: Lost Colony is meant to be played by five real people and it shows in the quality of the currently implemented bots. Firstly, due to the nature of the bots, it’s almost impossible to run a ship with only one human player so if you’re planning to get the game, make sure you find some people to play with. However, it is possible to play with 2+ players quite comfortably, having a captain and engineer as humans and the rest as bots is effective without overworking the humans. The reason I suggest this setup is because the weapon and pilot bots seem to be as good if not better than human players at those jobs as they’re easier to automate. The devs do plan to improve the bots later in development so hopefully things while improve.

Physics
Pulsar has several issues with physics in the game, I don’t know how realistic the devs want this game to be so perhaps these issues are in fact not issues at all but I’ll list them anyway. Of course I don’t expect them to have super realistic physics in the game but something less non-realistic would be nice.
Once you stop firing the ship’s thrusters it gradually comes to a stop, since space is a vacuum there’s no resistance hence you should remain at the same speed as when you stopped firing the thrusters.
Planets have no gravitational pull on your ship.
Some of the larger ship guns, have ridiculously large amounts of recoil, obviously there should be some force coming back from the shot (Newton’s Third Law if you’re interested) but significantly spinning the ship is over the top.
MiscellaneousThe audio is great in the game, the sounds that the ship makes are particularly good
There are already a few customisation options for you character including gender, hair style, hair colour and eye colour etc.
Personally I think the asking price is a little steep for Early Access but if you’re willing to pay a little extra than you’d expect and you know people to play with then I’d say it’s still worth it.
The devs seem very proactive when it comes to fixing bugs which are reported in the forum which is really good to see for an Early Access game.
It’s not beginner friendly at all, the manual doesn’t go into too much detail and it doesn’t really tell you how to actually operate the ship, Pulsar would definitely benefit from a proper tutorial.
Verdict
Worth Purchasing.

Pulsar: Lost Colony is a great co-op space combat game with a vast, randomly generated galaxy, several ships to choose from and fun, if not a little slow, combat. If you’ve always wanted a  co-op version of FTL, or if you’re just looking to scratch a space game itch, Pulsar may just be the game for you.

Review Copy Provided.

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pulsar: Lost Colony is a cooperative 1-5 player starship simulator, where you can pick up quests, battle enemy ships, explore planets and engage in hostile ground fights, beam aboard other ships and take them over or sabatage it.

The Basics
There are 5 roles available to choose from they are;
Captain; Give orders to your crew, modify your ship and manage your credits
Pilot; Fly the ship, collect scrap Align to warp nodes, evasive manouvering.
Engineer; Power Management; ensure the ship does not overheat, and when it does use coolant appropriatly
Scientist; Infect enemy ships with deadly virus' that can help turn the fate of the battle whilst keeping your cybersecurity online.
Weapons Specialist; In this role you'll be responsible for dealing the most damage to the enemy. You'll have use of the main turret right away which stock deals a ton of damage. You'll also help out on your ship to help repel invasions.
ReviewI've been playing PULSAR since Alpha dropped and it has gone from strength to strength, I've met some good crew mates who have become good friends since. The game captures the feeling of being aboard a starship superbly.
Of course this game is even more fun when You and your crew start to roleplay. I've lost count of how many times i've been yelling orders to my crew desperately trying to outplay the enemy startships. In my total play time i've had nothing but fun and I would honstly reccomend this game to any space fan.

One of my fondest memories so far was being in a fight against one of the sector commanders, it was a very long fight our ship was no way at all prepared for it but we all agreed to go hard or go home. After an exhausting battle and an extremely close call (We had around 30 hull left) we basked in the new found glory that we were truly unstoppable (After all, we killed one of the hardest Enemies in the game). Thats when poo started to hit the fan. We figured it was best to navigate to the nearest repair depot which was only 4 Warp jumps away (Close amirite?). So off we went, Engineer
date: prepare the warp core for activation" I said. "Helmsman
recommended: Align us to SE 42" I continued
hoursPlayed: barking orders. After which we left the battleground and was on our way travelling at warp speed along our journey. The first 3 stops were quiet
voteText: a planet to beam down to and explore
helpfulPercent: scavanged a few items and we were on our way. When we got to SE 17 they were there. Waiting. I quickly changed the alert code to defend the ship
votesHelpful: but I was too late. All three enemy ships had started to fire
votesTotal: our shields taking massive strain
votesFunny: our engineer was trying his best to allocate power accordingly but in the end it didn't matter
commentsCount: we weren't going to win this one. I knew that
column16:
and I believe my crew did too. We were overheating at a great pace and we were all out of coolant. Only one thing left to do I thought. "If we're going down then we are going to take them with us." I ordered our Engineer to disengage the reactor safety switch so we could eject the reactor. We did just that and managed to take two of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with us in the explosion that followed.

Of course no game is without its bugs but even the ones present here get hammered down very quickly thanks to Leafy Games' super quick hotfixes.

11/10 would try outsmart AI and blow up again"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never really written a review but this game really deserves one. (I hope it doesn't suck)

I bought this game last night and jumped on to captain my first ship! I was really excited hadn't done any research on anything just jumped straight in, As a warning this game has no tutorial [Yet].
Within the first 20 minutes I had a full crew. We all jumped on teamspeak and I meet a couple of great guys that I could enjoy this game with.
We were excited and ready to go! We warped we Landed, we died. Very quickly. In fact this happened several times. We weren't annoyed at our death, we talked to each other about what went wrong and what we could do to improve. We got excited to get out and kick some ♥♥♥  (Finally). By the time we started to win the action heated quickly and we where all having a blast. Each role has their own tasks and they're very interesting and require intricate cooperation so you don't die a horrible fiery death. Within the first few hours of playing we'd explored planets, completed missions and killed lots of bad guys (Without dying!!!). We upgraded our ship, shields, Core, Guns, engines everything. The upgrading of the ships is unreal and one of my favourite things to do as captain. After the 4 hour mark the games difficulty started to sky rocket, we could barely kill anyone, we where getting wrecked almost every time. At this point the science guy was finally able to start his role. Running programs to keep us alive and to stop the enemy ship from moving and or keeping  shields running. We finally started to do well again and then, they attacked. the enemy bored our ship and killed us from within!!! So now we have to run a ship and fend of pirates, ♥♥♥♥ yeah! We also discovered we could do this, send on two crew to get inside and shut down their reactor bail and kill them with ease. This is the limit of what I've done so far, so I'll go on to points about good and bad.

Pros: To sum everything up nicely.
- Pulsar is very cooperative, in fact working as a team is REQUIRED! Makes every player feel needed even if they're not blowing ♥♥♥♥ up.
- Pulsar has one of the best atmospheres ever. Sounds, shacking and lighting. It really sucks you into the action even though you're in a dark room with no windows, You know when you've been shot and you're in an epic space battle!!!
-  Ship upgrades add more depth and keep in interesting.

Cons: Please note this is a beta (Early Access review)
- The balancing needs work. The game is either too hard or too easy.
- Content, Yes I've played this game for 8 hours and I'm not bored. But this game needs some content, more ships, more exploration and more missions! We've done all the missions and making credits is getting harder...
- First person content, is fast paced and exciting. But is currently VERY limited and feels bland compared to space combat.
- An enemies feel and move like robots.

Some idea I had, thought I could share.
- Further ship upgrades, Shield resistance modifiers. Science already has one, but upgrades for that would be sweet.
- Drones! Little tiny helper ships of death, win/win if you ask me.
Hull Breach, You're standing in a room that has hole and got sucked into space, too bad. Not only would it be epic but it would make the room useless. increasing difficulty.
- Bombarding planets. You have big space guns? Why not take out enemies on the ground.
- Capturing enemy ships for parts. It should be harder to capture a ship, but the rewards should be greater too.
- More differences in ships, I should be able to have 10 guns on my ship! on 2 on my other ship. Or more main guns etc. OR even missile boats. So just missiles with bonuses to storage ect.
- Tractor beam, to get items from a distance.
- EVA, I should be able to go out of my ship in space to conduct repairs and attack the enemy head on!
- Upgrade to computers to include a library of viruses. You could load and unload programs, You keep the current max, But you can swap them out in battle to change your load out. It would need to have a load time like, It will take 2 minutes to transfer this program or something.
- Crew needing sleep and food, More RP like game play?

I think this sums it up nicely, Hope I make sense. This game has a bright future ahead. I won't say buy it now, But I've definitely felt like it was money well spent!

Keep up the work devs! You're making a one of a kind game that personally I've been waiting for!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a breath of fresh air! I haven't had this much fun playing a co-op game with people online in years.

My first time trying it  out I was on a small ship with one guy, neither of us having a clue what we were doing but we figured some things out enough to get somewhat comfortable with the basics of a couple of positions. Piloting the ship was straight-forward enough and so was manning the turrets. Time to look for a game with more people.

Next game I hopped in I was the pilot. Whenever I didn't know what to do the captain was kind enough to explain, and things were simple enough to learn. I played and learned with that full crew of 5 for about an hour.

Next game I was the gunner, also very simple to learn if you ever played any games in your life before, and I felt good being an important part of why we made it through fights with drones and other ships.

Engineer took a bit more of friendly people explaining what things did, but I found I didn't always have a lot to do so I continued asking questions so I would have some understanding of science and captain positions.

The next night I played a game as scientist and the crew had to explain a good number of things to me, but within an hour I had a full understanding of my duties and we played for 5 hours straight.
That's right. I played a co-op game with 4 strangers for 5 hours straight.
We explored planets, completed missions, applied talent points to improve or characters, collected scrap and upgrades and sold things we found to buy better ship components, and eventually boarded and stole a more powerful enemy ship by sheer planning, strategy, and team work.

I definitely got a strong Star Trek feel from the game, which was very much a good thing in my opinion, and in 2 days I felt like the game by far earned its price of admission, something so many early access games these games never do even up to completion.

The only downside was that the graphics are pretty dull overall even on highest settings.

9.5/10 for a teamwork based space co-op online game that is still in beta.

PULSAR is best described as a mix between Guns of Icarus and FTL in a open-world, and on a more sandboxy setting.
It's basically a very-light-starship-simulator where players take different roles. There's The Captain, The Pilot, The Scientist, The Engineer and The Weapons Specialist. So 5 players per session.

It sits on a very nice spot of not hardcore" and "not casual". So you can easily read the compact manual about a certain role

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is like playing as the crew members of an FTL game. Difficultly increases over time.  Each person has a role to play with their own responsibilities. Anyone can assume the responsibilies of another role, but there are perks and bonuses only available if you are playing a certain role.

Bots are available for single player or when you can't fill all the roles. AI for bots is quite lacking yet, so it is best played with other people.

Updates are slow, but consistent and meaningful. I enjoy it thoughly and look forward to each update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just got it tonight, and the first ship I get into is Captained by a very cordial Aussie. Took 10-15 minutes explaining things around the ship, and then my role in particular(Tactical). I knew some of it from watching Youtube, but I wanted to see how things were. We were already in space, and apparently our first goal was to board and take over the enemy ship. It was a rough battle, having to respawn multiple times before I realize we had taken out life support on the other ship, meaning there was no Oxygen...So after donning an environmental suit, I went over, neutralized the remaining crew and we took over the much more impressive ship.

Our next few warps brought us to a derelict ship, layered with mines. After clearing the field with our turrets, scrap was ours for the gathering. We then stopped off at a space port. We repaired, sold our scrap and headed back off. We had a few other officers join and leave, but Captain Rider and myself eventually met up with a particularly resilant ship. After taking twice as long to strip the shields, the captain decided we would take that ship. We stormed it, and with better training than before, easily destroyed the critical systems for their defense and claimed the ship.

Victory is sweet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I managed to play 23 hours in 2 days. This game is best played with friends and for people like me who have no friends, you can join public games or create your own.

Things to do:
- explore minefields, there is usually scrap
- upgrade the core
- save the game frequently
- buy more fuel

Things not to do:
- go afk at a black hole
- enter infected territory
- fight a security drone (not small) with modulated shields
- turn off the oxygen generator

10/10
One of the best games I've ever played, and it's still in beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review will be in english and in french. I'll start with the english one.
Cette évaluation sera en anglais et en français. Je commence par l'anglais.


Graphics

This game is very far from what we are used to in recent or upcoming games like Mad Max, Fallout, or Star Citizen (if we want to stay in the same game spirit).
You should not expect some amazing visuals in this game. However, the design of the ships, of the HUBs, and of structures on planets can easily make you forget the flaws if you like space operas like I do.
And even if you don't, there is something else that can get your attention : the possibilities in the gameplay.


Gameplay

I only played for about 7h at the time I'm writing this. However, I also spent a lot of time reading the manual for every role (quite useful for anyone who wants to be Captain, as you can learn all you need to know to give correct orders to your crew).
But I was absolutely amazed by how good the game system is. It's both complex and really simple. Complex because you need a slightly capable crew and a good captain in command to push your ship to its limits and discover all the possibilities the game offers. And simple because every panel speaks for itself and is understandable to anyone with at least 80 I.Q. The difficult part is to coordinate everyone.

Because it really is a coop game. With your friends or with stranger, you will need a good communication if you don't want to see your core explode your ship because your engineer forgot to apply the coolant liquid in the middle of a furious fight with a drone. Yeah, that can happen, trust me.
There is the possibility to play alone, with AI Bots in place of the different roles, but it's really not the same. And the Bots are still a work in progress and are not always responding as you'd expect.
A good thing is, there's a small but nice community of players and an official" teamspeak if you want to quickly find a crew and easily communicate with them.


What's in the game yet ?

Right now
voteText: a trade system for your ship at every station
helpfulPercent: few merchants in the main HUB to purchase better weapons or tools
votesHelpful: the possibility to explore some planets
votesTotal: 5 very specific roles to control your ship and even more ...\nRemember this is still an early access
votesFunny:
but it already has a buttload of stuff to do and discover.


All of that in two sentences ?

It's a better Star Trek game than any Star Trek game. It's really about managing your ship and going on an adventure

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I usually don't write reviews, but I think this game is very worth mentioning.

What is PULSAR: Lost Colony?
I would describe it as a 3D multiplayer FTL. The player, with up to 4 other crewmates, travels by the galaxy in a spaceship. Every person will be asigned to a role, being these the Captain, the Pilot, the Engineer, the Scientist, and the Weapons Specialist. Cooperation of all crew members will be needed to survive each threat they will encounter(mostly, enemy vessels or drones in space, aliens in planets).

I recommend to the person insterested in the game to watch some videos, because it really gives the sensation of being part of a vessel crew, giving a lot of tense situations, with the pilot running away from enemy shots, the captain giving orders, the WS trying to hit the enemy vessel and, when everything seems lost, the engineer screaming WARP DRIVE CHARGED AND READY
date: WE'RE ♥♥♥♥ING GOING OUTTA HERE" and jumping to hyperspace after an eternal time lapse where the drive took forever to charge.\n\nPerfect for playing with friends. It needs more content
recommended: but game gets updated every month with new features. I'm really looking forward for this game to be completed."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever wanted taking the captains chair on a spaceship?
Being a part of a five brave man manned crew, everybody equipped with special abilities on the journey of infinite space adventure?
Want to take your EVA suit on and loot out enemy forces in ancient alien buildings on planets no one has ever gone before? Then this game is for you.
Kinda repetetive sometimes but still addicting and challenging as well.


Level up the ship, level up your crew and lead everybody on board the way home, unharmed.
Complete missions, go for new ones, repeat, and face the dangers of endless space.

Between ground fighting, space battles and survival on an almost broken ship, everything goes for you and your team.
For now theres some content's missing but with a few friends and the EA stat in mind this is a reason for a weekend to spend on your very own ship, with your very own adventure.

A need for space adventurers and definitely worth the money.

This game is gonna be a big one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very impressive. I thought it would be another bad early access game as soon as I looked at the trailers. Much to my delight, I was wrong about this game.

As soon as I jumped in I had absolutely no clue what I was doing and went around and started flipping switches. This all would've made sense if I had just read the manual which is actually very useful.

As of right now, this game has a decent amount of content for being Alpha. There are also not that many bugs and apparently this is because the dev team actually want to focus on the bugs and roll out content in Alpha. The framework is strong so I think that the content will come fairly quickly and consistently once they reach that stage.

Multiplayer works amazingly. The Teamspeak integration allows players to enjoy the best in-game voice chat that I have ever used. Voice comes through crystal clear and doesn't have any real problems.

There are not really any major bugs that I have encountered so far which is one of the reasons I decided to pay for this game and not pirate it.

The dev team also does not plan on raising the price in the future so if you don't want to jump on board the early access train, you can certainly wait.

With that being said, I hope everyone purchases this as soon as possible so that the developers have more money to work with because they have an early access project that is actually worth funding and seeing through.

As of right now, I would give this game an  8/10. Performance could probably be improved a litte bit and the AI is a bit wonky. Combat is also a little frustrating right now but I know that it will be improved as time goes on. I really can't wait to see what all Leafy Games has in store and I know that once they reach release, this will definitely be a 10/10 game. No doubt about it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game. Yes, it's in beta. Yes, it has bugs. Yes, it's an indie title and it has a a small development team of two, but the developers fix them rapidly. The game has big potential as a fun co-op space exploration sim. Still lots of work to be done to get it where it should ultimately be, but even now it's quite playable and entertaining. It does get repetitive after a several hours of play though, but I believe that will change as the developers add more quests and content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello dear astronauts!

When I saw the trailer of this game I was sold. It had all the good stuff! Space exploration, space ships, space battles, space ants/spiders/robots, and it had space itself. I started playing it, and I just couldn't stop. Started out joining a random game where someone taught me all the basics. And hell, there are a lot of basics! Learning the game is pretty overwhelming at first. Untill you have played all 4 support roles it is hard to be the captain.

Thus, the day after the basics I decided to dedicate my day comandeering the U.S.S. Flying dutchman. I found some people, put them on a teamspeak and we played for about 8 hours straight. The experience was amazing! I lead us to planets, bandits, dronespaceships, and all there is to do. Everyone was immersed in their role, and achieving the goals I set for them. The one main problem we found out though was this.
After 8 hours of playing the game, we had seen it all. We had beaten both bosses, seen the infected ( which you cant actually kill yet.), been to all exotic shops, upgraded all the gear on the ship untill there was no proper match for us anymore. It was lacking content, but I kept longing for more.

Tl;Dr?

Pro's:
-Awesome gameplay. You are free to do w/e you want.
-Game really promotes player interaction. You have to function as a team. No soloing here.
-It is very immersive. You get into your role and stick with it almost naturally.

Cons:
-Some minor bugs. Server list not reloading, mines not blowing up, laser targetting messing up etc.
-Severe lack of content though this will most probably be worked on by the dev team!
-The game will take you and make you play it till theres nothing left to play. (might actually be a good thing)
-Game is quite boring without actual voice chat. (might be different for you)

Final verdict:
Buy this! But if you're patient enough, wait for a couple of months untill there is more content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy god this game is a winner. You've probably seen all the other reviews saying this game is like FTl, but in 3D. Well, that's exactly true. I'll add that the way you control all of the systems is by going up to a display and simply clicking on the buttons you want to select, no pressing an 'interact button' first or anything; it certainly adds an extra level of realism. This game seems as close as you could come to playing as a member of the crew on the starship enterprise, sprinting around and managing the ship's sytems.

I WILL say that in the current state (Nov. 5th, 2015), the universe is a little shallow, a few mechanics haven't been fully flushed out, and some of the player models and environment models still need a lot of work. But the game's foundations are strong. Some tender love from the devs could turn this into a staple game for all those space-sim lovers out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although I can't recommend this game in its current state to the general public, still being in Alpha, I very much adore this game. Those who enjoyed playing Artemis, or who love Star Trek and playing Escape Velocity back in the day will similarly enjoy this game even as is. The future looks very bright indeed. My only real critique is the pricing for the current state of the game; it should be lower. Nonetheless, $25 or so for this project will be well worth it down the road. I'm very picky with games but this is something a lot of people will enjoy.

Pros:
-Fun and imaginitive gameplay
-Star Trek lovers will appreciate for sure
-Not too complicated, and yet has some depth
-Good co-op teamwork required
-Some of the visuals look great already
-Great sound design for the ship
-Successful implementation of a game type rarely achieved
-Merges smoothly different genres of gaming together

Cons:
-Still needs more time to develop into a fuller game (it is in Alpha obviously)
For example: More content, more polish, more sounds, more of well, everything...
-Could still use more stability (Alpha)
-Still quite buggy (Alpha)
-Overpriced for its current state
-Not enough creativity in terms of ship customization or ship types
-Still a little clunky with its gameplay mechanic of first person shooter and point and click on panels" (although there is every indicaton that this will improve)
-Still missing a bit of clarity in terms of what needs to be done by certain classes"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very interesting crew / space sim where you play with 4 bots / other human players as crew of any of 5 spaceship designs.

Start the game up, join / create a game and take on the role of the captain, pilot, science officer, engineer or weapons officer and assist your colleagues in survival and completing quests by navigating through the galaxy, combat enemies in space, board enemy vessels and take them over, be part of away teams to investigate structures on the surface of numerous planets and upgrade your own and your ships stats along the way.

A very interesting concept, building on the idea of games like Artemis Bridge Simulator and adding a more RPG or personal touch. Run around your ship, that of your enemy, space stations, planet surfaces whilst assisting through the role you pick and excelling in performing in it.

The graphics are reasonably, but not excessively realistic. In a game like this I find graphics not as important as the mechanics and environments that provide the actual immersion. The game mechanics are such that the different roles one can assume really rely on eachother, but there are some things that could be improved in that department.

The sound effects are good, but again, in my opinion not as important as the game mechanics and the roles people fill with their characters.

There are still some bugs, and most environments tend to become a little dull after a while, but that's all work in progress. I would also love to see even more involvement of certain roles. The Pilot role for instance doesn't seem as important at times, and the available options for the other roles also seem a bit limited and could do with some expansion.

With the addition of in-game voicechat (which to be honest, I haven't tested yet myself, but I will later tonight) I think this game and its developers are going in the right direction, and I have high hopes for this title.

It is already well worth its price, well executed and incredibly addictive to play. Keep it up dev! ;-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pulsar Lost Colony has a strong foundation but is generally empty and shallow compared to what they're claiming should be in the game at this point.

Now don't get wrong, it's not a terrible game - but it's definitely at this point not worth the 25.00 you pay for it.

The AI is completely broken still, you're incapable of capturing multiple ships and there's a LOT of bugs with creatures/npc's/stations/bases.

As well the game is extremely repetitive and the majority of planets you visit are copy pasted. In the three hours I played I visited 4 desert planets and 3 frozen planets - all of which with repeated terrain and base layouts.

The combat is also the same each and every fight - you circle your opponent and shoot them until one of you dies.

Boarding is pointless - since you cant have multiple ships there's really no point to ever going onto the enemy ship. Upgrades are fairly easy to get within the first hour of the game, so that is also an issue.

Overall it's not a great game - I'd give it a 5 - as of right now it needs a lot of work and I would not suggest buying it for 25 dollars.

Sorry!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update for Beta 1.5
For original review, see below.

Half a year since I first played the game, I can say I'm largely disappointed. There have been 5 updates, of which 2 were advertised as 'major'. None of them addressed the issues that have been pointed by the community. The idea is still there, and there certainly have been improvements- however the game still fails to provide enough value for its' cost.

A good indicator of how PULSAR fails to keep people interested, even those that were initially excited about it, is the average playtime of the reviewers.
Its' bad retention rate can also be assumed from the very low number of average and peak concurrent players (http://steamcharts.com/app/252870#All)

I'll certainly keep an eye on it, and hope it will sometime fulfill its' potential, but at its' current state, price and rate of improvement, I wouldn't recommend purchasing it.


Beta 1.2 preview
Pulsar: Lost Colony is a very unique game. It draws heavy inspiration from genre-defining classics such as Star Trek and Firefly, and tries to provide a similar gaming experience, better than any game has so far managed to do. Its' mechanics might seem overly complex or even chaotic at first (and the lack of a tutorial doesn't help), but it doesn't take that long before getting used to how everything works.

Gameplay
A large portion of the gameplay consists of operating your ship through the use of monitors, flips and switches, controlling functions such as energy flow, offensive/defensive software, core temperature etc. Even though the UI can look archaic and out-of-place for an intergalactic spaceship, these monitors succeed in creating immersive and sometimes even frantic gameplay that rewards fast decision-making and combat awareness.
Another imporant aspect of Pulsar's gameplay is the ability to leave your spaceship, either to board enemy ships (for a manlier offensive approach) or to explore planets and outposts. Even though the concept is there, the excitement you get from visiting planets is doomed to be on a progressive decline immediately after the first few expeditions, since the ecosystems and architectures available are extremely limited at this point, and most planets' explorable zones are far too small and generic to be jaw-dropping. One can assume, though, that this is an issue that's going to be adressed sooner or later, as more content is being added, resulting in more randomly generated variations and hopefully more non-random, unique planets and outposts. Boarding enemy ships is also quite enjoyable, and allows you to steal initially unavailable spaceships.
Other parts of the experience Pulsar has to offer include piloting, manning turrets, trading parts to upgrade your ship, using public restrooms, turning interior lights on and off (for a superb rave party experience), isolating yourself in the captain's cabin as well as a currently lackluster quest system.

Classes
Role assignment is handled through five classes, each with its' own perks (available through leveling-up). The Captain controls the flow of the game and commands the crew, the Pilot steers the ship, the Engineer is responsible for the energy management, the Scientist ..uses software and the Weapons guy mans the turrets. Roles are fluid and can dynamically change during engagements, thus requiring effective communication between crew members, as is always the case with these kind of games. Even though the classes themselves are on spot, each one's gameplay isn't as deep or rewarding as the other's (with the Pilot and especially the Scientist suffering the most, as they have limited impact and almost no unique presence in the game).
Class talents are also in certain need of rework, as some are completely must-have whereas others fall into the meh/useless category, resulting in practically no choice over which talents to level and when. Their number is also limited- class talents can be maxed out after just a couple of hours.

Technical
Graphics are definitely not state-of-the-art. They certainly don't fail to convey the eeriness of space, but there's room for improvement, especially on characters and animations.
Sound is decent. The soundtrack could be more ambient and trippy- I feel the current background music is rather blant but I guess that's personal taste. The sound effects are especially well-made and convincing, and there's at least one for every major event (warping, taking hull damage, being set on fire, being shot in the face by a space-robot-bandit etc.)
Performance was flawless on a system just below the recommended specs, and I was even able to run it decently on a dated laptop just above the minimum specs.
Bugs do occur once in a while, and they can sometimes force you to quit and reload, but that's rather rare (2 forced reloads in 14 hours).


TL;DR+Great potential
+Fun, unique concept
+Well implemented mechanics
+Obviously made with love and passion
-Graphics aren't really great
-Limited content
-Classes and talents need work
-Game wouldn't let us warp away and leave our bossy captain behind in a desolate desert planet

Overall, the game is already super fun to play with friends, especially if you're into sci-fi. If you don't mind the occasional bugs (of which there really aren't thaaat many), the slight class balance issues, the limited content, the rather high price, and can look past the non-realistic graphics, I recommend buying this game. Otherwise, you may want to wait a bit for some polishing to get done and some extra content to be added.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A really good spaceship crew simulator. Very similar in crew roles and responsibilities to Artemis: Spaceship bridge simulator (also reccommended) with the added ability to go on away missions and added RPG elements to crew members and abilities.

Basically, become the crew of your preferred sci-fi universe and run the ship as though you were Captain Kirk/Mr. Spock.

Play as the Captain, Science officer, Engineer, Weapons officer or Pilot, each having their own roles, responsibilites, strengths and weaknesses for each situation you come across.

Not for people who want pretty, pretty graphics but if you like solid - if obviously incomplete gameplay, you'll love this. Crew stations and other mechanics need to be explained better but the game is pretty easy once you get the hang of it.

One thing that I think really needs to be added is the ability to have multiple crews - the galaxy is just massive and it'd take forever for a single crew to explore the whole thing. Teaming up (hell, even a head-to head mode) with other players would make this game incredible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

4 hours of game time during Early Access as of this review.

There aren't many games that offer space action, planetary adventure, sandbox freedom, and the intimacy of small player groups in sprawling game worlds. The team at Leafy Games have managed to bring these concepts together into this game.

It must be stated again that this is currently an Early Access game that does have it's share of bugs to stamp out, and content to develop. I'm eager to see what Leafy Games can do to make this a fully fledged release title.

Bugs that were encountered were few and far between as of this review. Only two came up during my time thus far:

-Attempted to transport to Outpost 448 after travelling for awhile and ended up teleported out into space. A quick relog fixed the issue.
-Helm control seems to give out unexpectedly. Unsure if this is a lag/network issue.

The concept is there. Bring me more!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pulsar is probably one of the best early access games out there on steam at the moment.

This game does infact have alot of potential, and just needs more frequent updates to get small bugs fixed.
One thing i think would be good for this game is, Make your own custom ship. This will add a lot more freedom for players and will be great for people who want to make massive battle ships.

Of course this is easier said than done, but i still beleive its possible. You could make it so the way you get parts for your ship is by collecting them from, say other ships when you destroy them etc.

The game also needs alot more planets and freedom to walk around them. I find myself stuck in one little part of the planet blocked off by invisible walls.

Another idea would be if you could be able to make your own weaponry for players and for your ship if you have enough crew members.

All in all the game is great for early access. It may not be worth 25 USD just yet but i beleive if the team sticks to the game and has frequent updates, this game can be really amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So... How to put this...
This is a freakin, AMAZING GAME.
Shall I simplify?
Nah I don't have to.
But I should.
Because it's awesome and you should know why if you haven't bought it already.
Which you should have.
Because its awesome.
Aaaaaaaanyway.

The graphics aren't great, but.. hey who cares? The gameplay rocks!
You have to work as a team or your ship will die, it has a very 'firefly, star trek, galaxy quest' style of gameplay where you all choose roles etc. I was the weapons specialist and my job was to fire big guns and be the away team, so essentially what you'd call a red shirt.
I always died.

The cons:
Well, it's beta, so there are a few bugs, and the diversity of equipment is low.
But that's all I found to gripe about.

In my first two hours, I:
Beamed down onto a lava planet in my exosuit with the crew and killed a bunch of slugs in some caves.
Went to numerous desert planets and icy planets.
Saw my Captain get swollowed up by some giant worm like thing.
Got eaten by a bunch of large ants whilst exploring some old ruins.
Blew up an enemy ship whilst my captain was aboard.
Got shot by some robot thingy.
And developed an unnatural fondness with the nuke we had on board the ship.

What a misfit crew we made.

So.... Essentially this game has been one of the most enjoyable games I have played of late; having found myself bored with games and desperately looking for some relief... This, this is the game. And in the first two hours I have done so much, bonded with the crew. It truly is one of the best games on steam, and is very worth the amount of money it costs. The development team listens closely to it's fans and is very active. I was following their youtube channel for a year keeping up with the dev logs.

Basically, buy it. If you like team based, explorative sci fi games that have the potential to create fun stories and scenarios, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pulsar is incredibly impressive considering the small dev team and their HUGE ambitions.  After years and years of competitive PvP and shooters its nice to have a game that forces players to work together.  Every team member has a special and crucial skillset.  In almost every encounter each member of the team will need to act quickly and coordinate their actions with each other.  Within a few warps and after a couple battles your teamspeak will inevitably start to sound like an episode of Star Trek.  The learning curve is a bit steep but rewarding.  I've played for 25 hours and still have encounters that surprise me, although the main weakness this game has is lack of content.  It can get boring fighting one security drone after another.  The team is adding more and more content and we get updates every week or two.  They are very responsive and professional.

DEVS IF YOU ARE LISTENING... here are a few suggestions...

-More varied alien creatures (humanoid, insectoid, reptillian, greys, etc)
-Special encounters with new species of life (a giant space squid that feeds off shield power for example)
-Ability for team members to become INFECTED by alien organisms that can break out of their bodies and infect other crew members...
-A medical officer position (and sick bay)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found that this game is surprisingly enjoyable.  The separation of duties of piloting a spacecraft made for a very quick imersion into the game.

I have yet to play all five roles that are available, each holds value and importance during you game play.  The five roles are as follows: Pilot, controls the actual flying of your vessel.  Scientist, handles tweeking of computer systems and cyber warfare to other spacecraft.  Engineer, runs the engine room and the over all power to the ship.  Weapons Officer, FIRE THE MISSLES!!!!!  Finally, the Captian, controls the navigation course and overall Captian duties.

You can travel from star system to star system, enjoying all the sights that space has to offer.  If you come across a planet you can go down and explore it.  There are deleric ships and spacestations that you can explore as well.  While star jumping/warp drving, some points can be inside terrain structures.  This terrian structures is one thing that caught me off guard, suddenly you are floating around inside a massive cave with crystals.

If you like star jumping, phaser blasting, space exploring scifi adventure, then this game is up your alley.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PULSAR: Lost Colony is actually a very well done game by a small indie developer, and it's about you serving and/or captaining a starship and going on a journey through space.

Been with the game since Beta 3, and I can assure to anyone thinking of buying this game that tons of progress has been made since then. The most recent major update in Beta 8 allowed you to hail other ships, instead of just flat out fight them the second you see them. It really adds to the immersion of the whole game.

With any game there's bugs, but none are overwhelmingly large enough to be game breaking and most are minor, for now. The devs have done a good job in QA testing their game and each update. Whenever they see a bug they usually do their best to fix it ASAP. Sometimes a bugfix will come in a patch version big enough to actually introduce a few tidbits of new content too. Always a good thing.

Some things are actually still missing, for instance; there's some key elements to the lore that are implied but not written in stone or shown in the game just yet. Updates have done their best to bring in more lore based content alongside meaningful core mechanics to the game. It should be made clear the devs are focusing on getting all core mechanics down first, before focusing on any big time content. Regardless, the game is still a bit vast in these initial stages.

Some people on the forums on the dev's website have suggested removing warp times and simply allowing a Captain to choose when to skip a warp. This would likely be a very good idea; if your ship has been damaged heavily in a firefight, being in that warp gives you the time to do what you can to get it battle ready, despite whatever shape it's in. Furthermore, let's say your crew is RPing? It would be perfect for RPing crews to use that time inbetween warps to socialize amongst crew and advance their own story. Despite these reasons, the devs have yet to make any adjustments let alone make any comments about this (to my knowledge). This so far, in my view, the only major con.

Pulsar: LC is a well done game. There are things that need to be done, but for what it is right now, it is a well done game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm skeptical about this game. It's in early access, which never really fills me with hope. However, from what I've seen so far, it shows a great deal of promise (which could be said for other games, really) and the developers are working tirelessly with the playerbase to stabilise and improve the game.
The game itself is an interesting concept. 5 players, each with their own role, working together in order to complete missions. Already it sounds like a number of games, but the way that Pulsar does this is not quite what you'd expect (unless you happen to expect something along the lines of guns of spacearus). Bots are available, but I'm writing this review with a Co-op impression in mind.
These 5 players are given a Spaceship and a role aboard it. Then, they're left to their own devices. The Galaxy is open to them from T minus 0, and there's quite a wealth of things to do. I recommend finding out firsthand. The game doesn't ease the player in very much. They are briefed on their role, but I learned quickly when I had someone talk me over the ship in a couple of minutes. Of course, there is some reading material that you could make use of.
The game doesn't hold your hand. The further out you go, the harder things are going to get. Work with your team and you can overcome all. Surely, this game has a thing for improving communication and building cohesion, However, I recommend a clear medium of communication, such as a Vent, person-person proximity, Teamspeak, and so on. As far as I am aware, there is no in-game VoIP. The options aren't great, and you may have an issue running the game. It's on Unity, I think.
I wish I could rate things out of 10 easily, but I don't really think that way. I think you could describe the entire game, so far, as Guns of Spacearus Online, the PVE sandpaign.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- This review was written as of Beta 2, during Early Access -

PULSAR: Lost Colony is a game similar to Artemis or Quintet, where you and your friends take command of a single starship and do battle with enemies. However, instead of flying around a single sector, there's an entire galaxy out there to explore with factions, hostile aliens, and several missions to give you and your buddies some direction.

Choose between one of five ships, and if you don't happen to like one, go ahead and board a ship of another type and take it for yourself! Upgrade your ship from parts of destroyed vessels or go on an away mission to a planet and look for salvage. There's something out there though, as my buddies and I explored we noticed some kind of infection sweeping over the galaxy and taking over as the literal chaos level increased. We haven't actually encountered it yet, but I read about alien monstrosities burrowing through the hull and attacking us from within.

It's Early Access Beta, and while the majority of the content isn't in the game yet, most of the core of the game is complete. Visit and walk around on space stations! Board enemy ships and capture them! Go planetside and search for relics, aliens, and clues to the titular Lost Colony! Go up in flames as your ship burns! Load the Nukes and pay them back with your dying breath! Boldly go wherever the hell you want with your only guide being how many credits you have left to gas up your tank, and your four buddies who might want to see what's JUST around the next bend - to blast it, analyze it, or turn it's leftover clink into some drink at the bar.

Early Access, yeah, I'm familiar with it. But I don't regret a thing this time, and I don't think you will either. This is the first best chance for a cooperative starship simulator in... ever. Throw some money at it, fund development, and get you some.

And hey, if you don't see any potential in it after you've had a look - steam refunds exist, so I say grab your friends and give it a shot.

RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We’ve all played games where we control a starship – smaller ships that could be manned by as small as a 1 man crew or some that needed thousands of hands. But in any case, we’ve always controlled that craft with simple mouse clicks, controls and joysticks. Well this is a breath of fresh air: this is what it would really be like to control a ship with a crew of five, each officer responsible for his station and ensuring mission success and survival. Does this new approach herald a great game, or does it fall short?

Check out my very in-depth review here:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had this for a while, but it took quite some time before it got into a state that I would call worth to play. Now however, this is definitely something you should pick up if running your own starship sounds intriguing to you. Get some friends together and explore, trade and fight.

The new mission system is great, it gives you cool objectives like finding out why a ship stopped responding, only to find them dead in space and infested with... something... :)

Movement is stiff, the gunplay is very basic - but there's enough dials, switches and screens to play with to make this fun top play nonetheless. You can play this alone with bots, or use AI to supplement your human crewmates. Hopping into a multiplayer game is super easy, even hosting a game behind NAT works without any manual configuration. Voicechat is built in, which is a giant plus. There's definitely a lot of polish still needed, but the last patches have added a lot of that, as well as major new features.

It's not finished, but definitely worth the price of admission. Get it on Humblebundle so you get a DRM free copy as well as a Steam key.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite a price to pay for the full experience with friends. However, if you are able to get a full group (5 people) of friends it creates a great experience. I've played a few bridge simulators and there are none better than this. There are 5 different roles and you cannot only travel around a 3D huge scaled ship, you can board other AI ships to take them over, land on planets and loot, and shop in local shops. Team work is required!

I would not recommend this title if you are playing solo since it is hard to find other teams to play with (especially if you do not have a mic!). The AI for your crew is not that great (but better than no one) and would again, would not recommend playing solo especially for a single player experience. Playing with random crew members can be hit and miss, especially since there are quite a number of players that feel the need to just wreak havoc to your ship just for fun.

Otherwise, if you can get a group, I highly recommend this title. Perhaps $25 is not the best price though. If this game was $10-$15 it would be perfect.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say having backed this game during its Kickstarter and having played very little of it, I have spent a long part of this weekend playing with a group of friends.

My first impression was poor, and I really didn't think I would play it ever again.

However, this weekend has shown me how much fun it is, the graphics are simple and plain, the gameplay is fun, whether your crew is taking out enemy ships, or boarding the enemy vessel to take out the crew, or on a ground mission, the game is fun.

Still feels a little empty in places, with planets seeming to have 1 or 2 buildings for the mission you're on, limited interactions, but it doesn't dent the fun factor.  Content can always be added, the difficulty is tough, but it is addictive..

Must have for groups of friends, its just good plain old fun, complex in places and satisfying once you crack it.

I am very happy to report my initial impression was horrificly wrong, and I now will be a huge promoter of this game.

I know we added 5 more players this weekend, and MORE will come..

I am so glad I backed this during Kickstarter..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do recommend this game, just not yet. This game is a wonderful concept, and quite frankly is the game I have been searching for on steam recently, and open-world, first person space sim-them up. And for an early access game, it has some great core mechanics in place and runs very smoothly on my R9 270. But it is just that, an early access game, and it doesn't quite have enough to warrant that £18.99 price tag. I don't particularly like the art style (personal preference) and would like to see it take a turn to the more realistic side. My point is this:
- It is an early access game, if you like to bug report and are really hyped for this game, then buy it.
- If you want to jump into a space sim game in the deep end with no tutorial (at the moment), then buy it.
- If none of the above apply to you, than wait. This will be an amazing game judging by what I have seen on steam and on the website. What they have planned for this is great. But at the moment, it doesn't have enough of the core mechanics in place. At least not for me. So what I'm doing and I recommend, is waiting until it is at a later build, or when it is fully released and buying it as a full game. It has great potential. Just lakes a few essentials for me at the moment.
(I know I didn't play much but it was enough for me)

I don't know how many people are working on and developing this. But keep going. You have a great concept and for and early access, a great game.

So, Pulsar Lost Colony... What I have found is that the game usually goes in this order.
You start a new game and become captain of your new ship, oh how amazing this ship is, some of your friends start joining and begin polluting your soundwaves with the sounds of their fire extingushers and the sound of the blasters as they start drawing profound images all over your ship. Next comes the unknown online players (if you have the game set to private) who, if your lucky, will not instantly try to sabotage your ship and then eject your core.
Once your crew is settled in and you spend the next 20 minutes gathering the missions from the station and purchasing the upgrades you want from the store you warp to the next sector to begin actually playing the game. However once you arrive you find an enemy ship and then it proceeds to one shot you, destroying your ship instantly...
Then you restart the game and it all repeats :D
10/10 would repeat the cycle again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pulsar: Lost Colony is one of the best cooperative games I have ever played


The graphics aren't that good, but noone really cares, because this game is awesome!

The atmosphere and style is great, and the sound design is very nice.


Everyone is dependant one one another. If one fails, everyone fails. And it's nice, because you can't be really good at this game, and just run the show all by yourself - you need other people.

The gameplay is simple, but engaging - you manage your screens/tools, and follow the captain's orders.

There are some simple shooting mechanics, and you can talk with all the npc's, and some of them have something genuinely interesting to say.

With the constant updates, and attention to detail, the developers show, that this game is something they really want.

It's nice to see that for once, and that they don't just take your money and run. (*cough* 'Ark: Survival Evolved' *cough*)


The end game is where this game doesn't really shine that bright, given it is in early access. But that will eventually be solved.

Overall, this game is great, but i suggest you buy it with at least 3 of your friends - it's going to be a lot more fun.

Final Verdict: 8 / 10
A great overall experience, that needs some polish and more content

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing the Early Access version of PULSAR and I have to say I'm impressed. I normally avoid early access after being burned by Dean Hall and DayZ but this game had me hooked within an hour.

The sense of exploration and adventure is really the focal point of this game, and they're things that a lot of games set out to achieve. The problem with most games out there is that their goals are attainable by just about anyone who picks them up. Challenges are set by the player themselves, and gaming (even in many multiplayer games) can feel like a very solitary experience.

PULSAR requires coordination with players (I really don't recommend this game unless you have at LEAST 3 other people to play it with) and that coordination is what drives this game. Suddenly it isn't the individual that chooses the difficulty and the challenge, it's everyone. You all work together and stand aside one another in the face of adversity--be it brutal enemy starship fights or exploration of labyrinthine caverns on distant worlds.

The devs have taken a very simple idea and made it into something very fresh and inspiring. It's hard to adequately describe the rush of emotions you get when winning your first starship fights as a team...or exploring sectors and sending away teams on investigations.

This is one of the few TRULY cooperative" games out there in recent years. I strongly recommend that fans of co-op games and sci fi/space games keep a close eye on this. If you aren't an early access type of person
date: add this to your wishlist and track it in its development."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PULSAR: Lost Colony is a cooperative game in a futuristic space faring setting.  Up to five players collaborate to tackle exploration and combat objectives.

Each player assumes a role in a small starship crew: Captain, Scientist, Pilot, Engineer, or Weapons Specialist.  Working together, the crew travels across a randomized galaxy to overcome various obstacles.  Exploration missions task the crew with travelling to remote locations to retrieve items or investigate an area.  Combat includes ship-to-ship battles as well as gunfights between individual players and opposing NPCs.  Enemy ships may be boarded and seized, or destroyed for scrap.

Each player has specific responsibilities.  The Scientist operates the ship's sensors, shield configuration, and opens communications with other vessels.  The Engineer manages the ship's power systems to ensure various parts of the craft are able to operate, without overheating the reactor.  The Pilot flies the craft and acts as the crew's eyes" - identifying hazards or items of interest that do not appear on sensors.  The Weapons Specialist mans the ship's turrets and acts as the craft's security officer.  Finally
date: the Captain (the player hosting the game) is the crew's decision maker - managing missions
hoursPlayed: and overseeing the crew's finances.\n\nSimply put
voteText: PULSAR: Lost Colony is a great game.  For a better understanding of the game (without playing it)
helpfulPercent: check out this gameplay video.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zwhbnW-o80c"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is astounding. I've been playing this game for as long as it's been available to the public, and you cannot believe how happy I get whenever I see a new devlog. The community is amazing. They're friendly, welcoming, and accepting, and the developers, unlike many early access developers, keep in close touch to the community. This is one of, if not the best, space sims ever.

The game has a bit of a steep learning curve, but with the helpful community, new players can learn quickly. On your first play through, you'll find yourself putting several hours in without even noticing. This is one of those games that you can just sit, and play without stop.

I really think that this is a worthwhile game to buy, even in its present form.

- Happy Voyaging!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is fairly light on hardware, but packs a lot more underneath. At the moment, the game has a few recycled textures which allows it to run fast.

The ships at the moment are limited. However with the introduction of the Roland-class, we can see a potential for larger ships and perhaps hybrid AI/Human crew. Each ship has their own unique traits or abilities which allow for different styles of play. However the end game items overshadows these abilities which results in the same endgame play. Ship systems as of Beta 1 are moderately balanced however with AI controlled turrets, the main turret becomes less of a priority to man since the AI can hit it's target most of the time when you have a good pilot.

The ground combat at the moment is a good step in the right direction. Variable landscape that change how the player has to adapt. The new environmental suits allow you to travel to dangerous locations without harm and the weapons are based on a tried and true trade-off method (one shoots fast but weak, one shoots slow but fast, etc.). At the moment, the gameplay requires players to dodge gun fire or melee attacks. Requires every little tactical movement when shooting back so players can easily duck behind cover to protect themselves. Player customization is fairly fixed on implants and tattoos, but allow for colour changes. Otherwise the customization is vast on hairstyles, facial and colour options.

Like to see more in the future from Leafy Games, but I would deem this a playable Early Access and recommendable to anyone who enjoyed Star Trek: Elite Force with a mix of Artemis Ship Simulator.


(Psst, my YouTube Channel if anyone wants a peak of all the things that have progressed in game: https://www.youtube.com/user/nawkcire)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS: Very cool concept(would love to see more of this style of game). Good devs. Lots of potential. It is funny how easily random people who join your crew can get into their roles both in terms of mechanics and role playing. The Captain is usually treated as the Captain and so on. There is a large galaxy to explore. Upgrading your ship and crew skills adds some sense of progression.

CONS: The content in the game is quite limited at the moment(though there is enough to sink your teeth into). The graphics are basic but it still has a decent aesthetic.

I look forward to the eventual fleshing out of ship's systems, crew abilities, AI interactions, missions, and planetary exploration. Like I said there is a lot of potential and a lot of features that can be added.

At around 17 hours I feel I have gotten my money's worth so anything extra is just icing on the cake.

Early Access Review

It's an all around great experience. While the graphics leave much to be desired compared to modern games, if you're going to judge games based on graphics then you will miss out on some series gold.

This game makes players work together, otherwise you won't get very far. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cant say enough great things about this game.  The developers are true gamers, they seemed to add in everything you could of ever wanted to a co-op space sim. It is still early but the game shows a huge amount of promise.  Dont go in expecting next generation graphics like ARK or flawless AI, go in looking for something orginal and well thought out.

Pros:
Unique play style.  Nothing really like this out there
Everyone has a job to do.
It really is epic.  They have a cool piloting mode that lets you fly the ship with wasd and the mouse. You just have to experience it.
Quest...check.  Huge random open world...check.   RPG elements...check.  Random encouters...check.  Ship to ship combat...check.  Board enemy ships or get boarded...check.  Beam down to planets...check.  Fly in wrecked stations for loot...check.

Cons:
AI helpers are ok at best.  They pilot like crap and barely do anything more than take fire when you are boarded.  The developers are working on that.
Character graphics are just plain bad.  Doesn't really bother me but some people might have a problem.  It is about game play and it is in beta.
You need friends.  Get on reddit or look at forums plenty of people out there who want to fly if you dont have any buds.
Wood panels on the floors in spaceships.  Dont know how I feel about that.

Final thoughts:
Pulsar brings a lot to the table and in a very early version is more than playable for many many hours.  If the big boys like Elite, SC or STO every figured out how to implement this level of co-op into thier games we would have a tough time figuring out what to play.  This is what STO should of been and what Elite and SC could have to make them true winners.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[DISCLAIMER]: Everything I say here is of MY opinion. Don't get all mad because it doesn't allign with your opinion.

I have been following this game since it first came out on greenlight. This was around the time I still played Artemis: Spaceship Bridge Simulator and what this game promised was that game, but ten billion times better. First person ship bridge simulator is exactly what I wanted and I'm happy to say, this game delivers like there is no tomorrow.

The game like I said is a first person multiplayer spaceship exploration/combat simulator. I first got the game when it was in early alpha and even though it was very rough, the game still had tons of features and charm. You and perferably 4 other friends begin their journey on one of the five ships avaible (ATM) each with its own personal style of play and interior/exterior looks. One of the things I was really looking for in this kind of game was ship system interaction. By this I mean as a player I control the ship in anyway I want. Its not just go forward and back, shoot weapons, and so on, I can control where the power goes around the ship, I can scan the sector for enemies, I can use programs that boost stats or viruses that infect enemy computer, I can tweak what subsystem need power from lights to atmospherics. The goal of the game is go through this procedurally generated galaxy and kill enemies for scrap. Once you do so you buy upgrades at shops and equip them on your ship. After this you will eventually be powerful enough to take on the galaxy boss and claim victory. On the way to this main goal there is so much to do and see so lets go over some of that.

Things to do:
1. Kill enemies.
2. Loot abondoned space stations and structures for scrap all while avoiding dangerous mines.
3. Find a high class enemy ship and prepare to board!
4. Kill everything last thing on this enemy ship and hack is subsystems to take control of it!
5. Use your new sexy ship to fly to a planet.
6. Use your teleporter and beam down to the surface.
7. Don't forget your space suit because humans need oxygen.
8. Explore abondoned strucutes on the surface for food, weapons, collectables, and more!
9. Tell your friend to walk out into the desert by himself/herself but DONT tell him/her about the evil sand worm.
10. Find sector 0 and enter the famous Colonial Hub and meet new people and accept quests!
11. Get lost in the Colonial Hub
12. Fly into a sector with either a high level enemy or many enemies
13. Panic because you shields are down
14. REALLY panic because your ship is blaring its sirens and there are lots of red lights and evERYTHING IS SHAKING OH GOD
15. Die
16. Return more motivated than ever.
16. Pay taxes to use the Long Range Warp Station to move around faster.
17. Spend skill points to make yourself and your kick-♥♥♥ crew even better!
18. Customize your apperance.
19. Try to overthrow the captain.
20. Fail at mutany
21. Get ingrossed in something and forget about the heat level of your reactor.
22. Panic AGAIN because all your system turned off due to emergency cooling.
23. Wonder what this switch does and eject your loving core out into space (What did it ever do to you!?)
24. Run out of fuel and have to open up your emergency broadcast beacon.
25. Pray to the space whales that someone nice will come to your aid.
26. Die from someone not so nice.
27. Get determined to win the game (or at least progress as far as you can in the games current state)
28. Do the process all again but not die
29. Get hype for you epic finale boss.
30. Pump your epic music so that your parents get annoyed.
31. Shoot the crap out of the boss using your skills and that handy dandy nuke you forgot about.
32. Revel in your victory and attempt to self destruct the ship.
33. Die
34. Give this game a thumbs up on Steam because of how awesome it is!

What I covered about is not all that you can do. Its an open world space game so you can make up stories, role play, and gather your buddies for a awesome LAN party thats not actually LAN because the game doesn't have that feature yet BUT it will. Anyways this game is great on almost all sides. I didn't even mention it but the art style is very clean but detailed and easy to look at. All in all I can give this game tons of my love and I think you should too! If your reading this and you know you could even slightly enjoy this game then you should really click that buy button. Lastly the devs to this game are super open about their development and are awesome dudes. They would love to help you with problems and so would the Pulsar community. The devs even have had polling sessions to vote on content that will be in the game! So buy the game or don't, if you don't your missing out on the best open world spaceship bridge simulator to date.

If you would like to see more I have a series of the game where me and some friend try our best to plow to the final boss. I will put a link to the first episode if you want to watch it.
