reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a brilliant game, you are part of a crew of 5 on a space ship, you can play with real players or with bots. When you're playing you're not just pressing E (or in this case R) on a console and that automatically cools the core, you need to lower that power usage or turn on the coolant (or both). Are the programs out of charge? Get your butt in engineering, load that fuel cell, and pull that lever. Want to know what that enemy ship has, scan it and see its power usage, components, status, and what type of ship it is.

You play as one of five roles, The Captain, The Pilot, The Weapons Specialist, The Engineer, and The Scientist.
The Captain is self-explanatory, they orders the crew around, and is in charge of trading, diplomacy, that sort of stuff.
The Pilot is also obvious, they pilot the ship, evade, align the ship, and give weapons a clear shot.
The Weapons Specialist is usually controlling a massive super cannon, which is fires powerful lasers and missiles.
The Engineer keeps the ship cool while at the same time giving everyone else enough power to work with.
The Scientist will perform research, cyber warfare, scanning, and is generally the go to guy for getting to know what's going on.

You explore though space, teleporting onto stations, exploring planets, and trying to find the Lost Colony.

The website probably explains it better than so here Link to website[www.pulsarthegame.com]




tl;dr version: Starship simulator when those buttons actually have a purpose.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BUY WITH WILLING FRIENDS!!

What is it: FTL with Friends!

This game is actually super cool! The whole idea and concept is honest just a dream game if you want to be running LANs or just want a good game for you and the buds!
The basic idea is this, You and your friends are in charge of running a spaceship, so you'll need a pilot, a weapon specialist, a scientist, an engineer and of course, a captain. then you just go exploring the depths of space! completing missions and the like!

PROS:
Decent multiplayer! didn't have much trouble connecting, making a server, and the server lag wasn't ever a problem.
Gameplay seems solid! the controls and weapons all seem to function well! the weapons aren't too exciting yet though.
Pilot and run your own spaceship with your friends! This all works awesome! the piloting controls, and the whole UI is great if you are changing things in the menus and various panels found throughout your craft.
Jobs are actually fun! the jobs are surprising all filled with interesting things to do at almost every moment of gameplay, no real down time or dull moments for anyone! though admittedly, Pilot and Engineer have the most to do, and the most responsibility.
Go to planets! You can actually go to a variety of planets and fight monsters, aliens, robots or the general populace for the loot found about the place!
You can level up and upgrade your character! You can actually pick from a decent selection of perks that improve your job efficiency, and get a variety of armours and weapons along the way!

CONS:
Shooting isn't so great yet: With the exception of spaceship shooting, the FPS gameplay is weak, but functional. with work, this will be much better in time I imagine!
Planets can be dull: Some planets can be strange, or seem very.... glitchy. This part definitely feels the most unpolished, but I'm confident it will improve with time.
Navigation can be awkward: Too often we got a mission at a such-n-such location, and we had no clue how to get there. I think some work needs to be done in this area.
Progression is Minimal: The character progression is fine, but the ship progression seems non-existent. to my knowledge, you cannot upgrade your ship to another ship, merely attach upgrades to certain parts of the ship. This is all well and good, but once you start making coin, it would be cool to be able to buy a new spacecraft to use in game.

THINGS THEY SHOULD INCLUDE IN THIS (AWESOME) GAME
-Campaign Mode: A full story to experience with your friends spanning a good 6 hours or so! with firefights, exploration, science stuff, and diplomacy! I would love that kind of experience, making the tough decisions as captain, putting controversial decisions to a vote for your crew, or possibly facing Reaper-ish foes! It would be fantastic!
-Custom-Made Missions: This would fit into the campaign side of things, but A mission builder type of system would be awesome! You could make entire missions or campaigns to then play with friends or share online, with the option of including voiced dialogue and tree-style story elements!
-Launchable Starfighters: It would be awesome if in the event of a large battle, a launchable craft could be made available to aid the mothership in violent incursions! This could also open the door to additional exploration options!


In closing, this game is freaking great! It is missing a little shine and polish, but is very reminiscent of the Mount and Blade" series
date: which is definitely a good thing! just add a bit more scope
recommended: and some more cool doo-dads here and there

Put together your team with a proper strat caller,awper, support, and always have a good lurk to catch the rotates in repair/warp stations.

On a scale of cobblestone to dustii this game is a solid mirage, and if it continues to be developed and fleshed out has all the potential to be as good as dustii.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is reminicent of FTL, but does plenty to differentiate itself from FTL.  It's in 3D and has 5 man online co-op featuring 5 unique roles: a Captain, a Scientist, an Engineer, a Pilot, and a Weapon's Specialist! Each role has it's own bonuses, a rudimentary skill tree, and different things to do such as steering the ship, hacking/scanning, manning turrets, fixing the ship or bossing people around.

I've had some great moments in this game. As the engineer, there's nothing quite like pulling off Scotty like miracle work and saving the ship with last second engine repairs and then punching the button that jumps you all to safety. Similarly when there's a virus in the computer, rebooting the computer involves some Jurassic Park style flipping of big switches that always makes me chuckle to myself every time I see them! They're great. As the pilot I got to show off my piloting skills while gingerly easing the ship through the tight passages of an ancient wrecked structure and navigating around dangerous mines as we tried to salvage some loot. As the weapons specialist there was a moment when we bit off more than we could chew, with our ship blazing, and our weapons knocked offline I made a snap decision to board the enemy ship at the last second and managed to destroy their weapons, haulting incoming damage just long enough for my crewmates to jump the ship to safety. As the captain the first adventure was a blast, with me totally clueless but leading a crew of seasoned veterans, and they just rolled with it, bless them. It was a disaster, but everyone had fun. The scientist is the most underapreciated role, but they have their uses such as scanning for lifeforms and modulating shields. Although underappreciated, I take secret pleasure in joining a game as the scientist. I've heard rumours that there will be some form of scientific research added at a later date to flesh out the role a little more, and I do hope so.

You can do some similar things in Pulsar that you can do in FTL such as boarding enemy ships, targetting their subsystems, hacking, shutting off their oxygen (or your own), causing/putting out fires, shopping, and upgrading your ship. There are some things you can do in pulsar that you can't do in FTL such as beaming down to planets, visiting space stations, comandeering enemy ships. There are some really nice touches, such as when you grab cargo, that stuff starts appearing on cargo pads in your ship. So when your ship fills up with cargo, it literally does fill up with cargo. Really adds to the immersion.

The galaxy is open world which to me is a huge plus, so there's a lot of freedom to roam the galaxy as your captain pleases. The open world doesn't extend to planets, with surface areas being small areas around the teleporter pad, more akin to dungeons than planet surfaces. But they are certainly functional enough for their purpose.

If you're lookng for something to play at the weekends with friends then there is definitely a lot of fun to be found here. Get 4 friends wth you and hilarity ensues. It was watching a live steam of people playing this that made me instantly buy it!

If you're looking for an FTL-like game you can follow the development of and play occasionally when patches come out then this is a good buy. Judging from their past dev-videos, new content comes approximately on a monthly basis with bugfixes and tweaks more regularly. If you like the concept and are willing to support a dev on the potential of their game alone then you will probably not be disappointed, Personally, I played pulsar for 2 days solid, and stopped playing it, only because I don't want to play it to death at this early stage. I know there is still a lot of content needs to be added and so it's better to only dabble in it for now. So now I just play it for a bit when patches some out.  The base game is complete, and all the core mechanics have been fleshed out to where it's a fully fledged game. There is a large galaxy to explore and missions you can play through. All that is lacking is a decent variety of content to keep things interesting in the long run. To be sure if you're looking for something that you can play all day long, every day, and never run out of content, then this is not the game for you--at least not yet. But if you're looking for something to dabble in until the developer has a chance to flesh it out more then I heartilly recommend.

As with all Early Access games there's no guarentee it will ever be finished, So really it comes down to whether you're willing to support the developer on the merit of what they have right now and on the future potential. Keep in mind your idea of fleshed out" might differ from the developers. I've been burned before
date: *cough* Elite Dangerous *cough*. But I still see it as worth the risk to support smaller devs such as this when they have something that really appeals to me. If you're not sure then check out youtube
recommended: or better yet wait till release and you'll know for sure."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An intriguing little game with lots of ambition. It aims to be a glorious mashup of Artemis: Spaceship Bridge Sim, FTL, Guns of Icarus, and Star Trek: Away Team, and while it is admittedly a little light on content at the moment, it does a great job of capturing the essential components and atmospheres of all these games.

Players get to choose between four different ships to fly in, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, and five classes to play as: captain, pilot, weapons, engineering, and science, each with their own disticnt roles and RPG-style progression trees. At present, you start at The Hub, an expansive space station from which you can purchase items, weapons, and ship components, and also pick up various missions that drive progression in the game. Gameplay involves FTL-esque flight between randomized sectors, replete with derelict ships, crazed security bots, and enemy capital ships. There's also Away Team segments, where you can teleport down to nearby planets to fight the aliens de jour and search for your mission objectives. There are some neat metagame mechanics at work too: factions, reputation, and a Galactic Chaos system that ramps up the difficulty of enemies as you play. Apparently there are also some other surprises in store further out in the galaxy, but I haven't made it far enough out without getting vapourized to encounter them.

All in all, it's a super promising little title with great atmosphere and ambition that's just a little short on polish and content at time of writing, but is still a blast to play. Best played with friends! You can yell at each other to charge the warp core as you are torn apart by AI bots.

Overal Verdict: Pre-Beard Riker -- full of potential, and just waiting to fill out into a space-age icon.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very impressive game. 5 players get a spaceship, and adventure around the galaxy doing anything they like. The classes are all well designed, though the Scientist and Engineer could do with a few more responsibilities. The ships and their class-related functions are easy to learn how to use - after my first game" (30 minutes of gameplay
recommended:
everyone left) I had mastered a role and learned quite a lot about another two. The enemies (generally) aren't over- or under-powered, unless there are more than about 3 of them, in which case one should leave. Quickly.

One of my largest problems was the character model quality. While it doesn't affect gameplay, I'm very fussy when it comes to graphics quality. Also, there could be a bit more variety in terms of the ships (not the components, the ships themselves).

I do think that the price was a bit too high, however. Personally, I would have been more willing to pay around £15, rather than £18.99. Alas, not many things are perfect - but this game isn't too bad.

Overall: 8.3/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So firstly the Dev's of this game are insanely detected about this.

Open-world Space & Planet exploration game, 5 player co-op, you'd think that'd require a huge development team.
Nope, not only have the guys at Leafy Dev's done this on their own but they've done it well!

Still in Beta and there's already a ton of stories me and my friends are able to share back and fourth about our exploits, which are often made even more special because we experienced this together, and together having to essentialy synchronize as a team, so when we earned something we damn well earned it!

If you want a game where you and up to 4 other friends can take a space ship and just explore the Galaxy like they do in Star Trek this is by far the best game that let's you do it in a fun, engaging and memorable way. With five distinct classes of Captain, Weapons, Science, Engineering and Pilot.

If you're a space exploration fan, have some friends and want a truly engaging experience this is *the* game in my opinion. The only thing I feel the need to pre-warn is that being in Beta the Dev's are still working out the Balancing of the game, so you might get stages where it seems a bit too easy or (my preference) a bit too hard.

Keep up the great work Leafy Devs! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my dream game. The game I've been waiting a long time for. Ever play a space ship game when thought about wanting to walk around the ship in first person and have it be in co-op? Well, this is the game for you.

Pulsar: The Lost Colony is a space ship game where you and 4 other players go on a space adventure on your space craft, exploring the galaxy while maintaining your ship and resources. It's like FTL in that the game is randomized at any time and will run into situations where, if handled poorly, will spell doom for your crew and ship.

Each player is divided into 5 different roles: The Captain, Pilot, Weapons Specialist, Scientist, and Engineer. Captain manages the ship, pilot pilots the ship(duh), WS focuses on manning the ship's guns, scientist acts as a team medic, coms specialist, and researcher, and engineer makes sure everything is working properly. All of them are important to your success in your deep space voyage, but you can get by with just 3 people if you don't have anyone else. Each role has skills that you can upgrade as your crew, not you, levels up, each tailored to that class. Anyone can operate one class's role as a different class, but you won't be as effective than you would be as that particular class.

The big part of this game is that you can actually walk around the ship, even while it moves. Considering how multiplayer games tend to have wonky physics when it comes to players on top of moving objects, it's pretty impressive. Each ship has rooms that are tailored to each role, but there's even some fluff that make the ship feel more authentic, like a crew lounge, bedrooms, and bathrooms. As of this review, there are 6 ships in the game, each differing in size, layouts, and stats. No two ships are exactly the same.

Gameplay outside of the ship consist space battles, visiting ships and space stations, and finding planets that you can teleport down to in order to explore it. The galaxy is randomized every time you play, so each adventure will play out differently. The isn't much content here yet, but with it being early access, I can forgive it.

As for the early access model itself, the devs are pretty good at keeping the community updated. The post monthly updates, have a roadmap on what the overall plan for the game is, and they say what they plan to work on for the next update. This game has been going on for a couple years, so it seems Leafy Games is using the model properly.

Overall, it's a great game to play with friends. People might be turned off of by the $25 price tag, but I enjoy the time I put into it. If you like space games with co-op, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing! It's a multi palyer crew spaceship sim. Basically what Star citizen is going to be jsut on a lower graphical scale.

Currently it's in alpha and feels like it. A good portian of the mechanices are still not implemented and there is no tutorial. The only way to learn how to play and what's in and what's not is to open the menu and click View manual.

Basically when you first join the server you pick your role: Captain, Pilot, Scientist, Weapons Specialist and Engineer

The Capt. Pulls all the info from everyone together and tells everyone what to do (this person should know how to play, they should be ableto guide the others) The capt also buys and sell stuff and is more or less in control of the money.

The Pilot, moves the ship. To warp he has to line up up the ship and the engineeer has to press a button. The pilot doesn't.

The Weapons Sepc. Shoots the gun (and main gun).

The scientist has the best job in my opinion. They send viruses to enamy ships, they clean the system of viruses, they scan everything, the look up info on verious stuff and run good programs to boost shields give more thrusters ect.

The Engineer has the hardest job and in my opinion the 2nd best job. They have to prep for ward, balance the power core temp, turn the power on and off, and provide a boost to the scientist. You may not THINK thats a lot but when everone else uses there stuff it messes with your temp.

There are diffrent parts ofthe ship that can be damaged and needs repaired to keep that part going.

It feels a lot like guns of icurus but in space.

Like i said before; currently there is a lot missing of the game. but from whats not working, this game is going to be awesome!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After buying the game, and after the rest of the afternoon disappeared...

Wow, that was a fun 2 hours. I looked at the screenshots, and read the reviews, but nothing really prepared me for the expirience. Logging into a multiplayer game was easy, learning my way around the ship was easy, even the ships control system were intuitive and easy to learn.

but keeping your ship level and unharmed when enemies are hurling missiles at you and the weapons guy is a real noob on deflection shooting and keeps shouting for you to hold the ship still for a second while flying through an asteroid, that's hard

After a couple of missions and visiting mabe 4-5 different crews, I created a single player game, so I could learn how to actually controll the ship. The smallest flies like a dream, and the biggest I've flown so far had more guns than my Grandpaw and drove like his Ford Galaxie 500

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Five astronauts! One spaceship. Infinite possibilities?

If you ever wanted to control a spaceship together with 4 other real players, this might be the game for you. The flight controls, engines and subsystems are all operated from computer terminals, located on the bridge and other places inside the ship. Players must coordinate their actions to effectively repel enemies or even jump from one sector to the next. While it's the Captains job to take over this coordination (and drink coffee), the Pilot controls the movement, the Weapon Specialist operates the gun turrents, the Scientist the ships software and scanners and the Engineer watches over the energy usage and temperature of the core.

Gameplay example: If you need your weapons to reload faster, the Engineer can switch of systems like internal lights and air conditioning to reroute more power to the weapons or he may switch of shields to have even more power available. The Scientist can temporally boost certain systems with his programs or he can try to hack the enemy ships systems. Of course you can't use all systems on full power at all times, since your ships core will heat up dangerously. Gameplay is often described as Faster Than Light in 3D and Coop.

You can board enemy ships and fight AI crews, explore planets, loot candy and go shopping in space stations. On your travels you will find scrap to sell or ship parts to instal. It's important to plan a route that passes by repair stations to repair the hull or upgrade with new parts. Also you want to stock up on fuel, missiles and coolant fluid used to cool the core in the heat of battle.

At the moment there are 5 ships to choose from, all different in size and layout. They all have beautiful lounges to relax and one even has a bar. 10/10 points for that alone.

In the end of the day it's a very fun coop-experience, you want to share with a group of good friends OR the very nice community.

In future I would love to see more things to do onboard except operation the ship. How about some mini games to pass the idle time (btw: there is no idle time, if you don't want. You can jump into action in less than a minute) or enable Roleplay.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is one of a kind.  The closest thing I know of is artemis bridge simulator but that is more of a lan rpg.  This is my dream game.  A 5 player co-op first person version of FTL.  I'm surprised it took such a small indie studio to even attempt such a thing and yet it is coming along at a remarkable pace.  I was an original backer and played the game since its barely functioning alpha release February of 2014.  At this point in development there is definitely enough content to have a blast with 4 other friends.  The story and mission content is still forthcoming and furthere changes will likely be made to the existing 5 classes but I would definitely recommend picking this game up if you can convince a few friends to join you.  Pick up groups with randoms can also be fun.  I would only warn against playing alone with bots since the AI is not fully implemented.

The best way to think of the game is essentially a 3D FTL that you can play with your friends, combined with the Star Trek simulator we've always wanted.

Even if you don't get it now, keep an eye on it and come back when all the content is added.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: I am the captain you don't want as your captain initially. Overtime, you will come to appreciate what you learned on board my ship. I wont know of it, as I likely wont remember you.

General rules of when I captain a ship:
1. Do your job, not mine. Nothing is worse than a self-promoted lieutenant or lieutenants. Maybe being marooned in space is worse.
2. Learn your task. Often, the best way to learn is for us, as a crew, to die until you either quit or gain experience.
3. We don't save so don't ask. We go as far as your patience holds out.
4. If I'm blue, it means I am captain not you.

Pros:
1. Unique concept: Very few games have this level of cooperation and mayhem combined with mutiny and betrayals.
2. Random game play: No two sessions are completely the same. The crew changes, the ship changes, the galaxy changes, and hopefully, you change as well.
3. Work together or die: Your life is in the hands of your colleagues and vise versa. Work together and get blasted, repeatedly. Maybe this time, you'll live to see another enemy.
4. Person, not a ship: Be a human in space doing exploration as well as ship combat. You are not the ship, you are its crew, with plenty of details to reinforce that fact.
5. Sporadic combat: One second you're alive, waiting for the next jump. Next second you're dead, waiting for a restart or rage quitting. Which are you?

Cons:
1. Incomplete: Much of the features are flat out missing, with plenty of room to fill holes in game play.
2. Low customization: The ship may change but among limited selection. The same applies to the player's looks, the ship's parts, and the crew's weapons.
3. Limited play styles: Boarding actions, planetary engagements, stealing ships, and piracy are just a few underdeveloped, dead end activities that are more for fun than profit. Although amusing, don't expect much advancement from certain activities.
4: Abnormal logic: Ramming does minimal damage, despite ship size. Crew members cannot jump without jet packs. Exo-suits cannot use jet packs. The list goes on.

The game has great potential, but we shall see if such potential grows or is squandered by the games first anniversary.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although the idea of working with team mates to control a ship may seem very appealing, that is all that there is. No storyline, the bots are atrocious (both friendlies and enemies), no pvp feature, the game gets very repetitive very fast since jumping into a system will always yield one of four possible scenarios and the planets aren't much better either. In fact the only thing I enjoyed about this game other than working as a team was upgrading my ship but even that lost its appeal when you come to realise with the majority of the enemies that you'll either always win or always lose regardless of what gear you have installed.

This game had really great potential and I really wanted to like it, but it just doesn't perform.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has SO much potential, and is one of the first games I've come across that has a true co-op feel that is a good mix between Firefly meets space combat game.

However, the new update has completely broken what is already challenging gameplay, even for the the most experienced of space sim pilots. The AI bots are now more useless than ever, and running into even the basic of battles means almost always certain death. You rarely get a chance to level anything on the ship now, and if you do the permadeath model means you're back to square one if you happen randomly into the wrong sector.

Until the devs do a basic re-tweak of simple gameplay mechanics this game is not worth the Early Access dollars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Deceptive trailer.

Buggy, repetitive and shallow gameplay.

Like flying ships? Ship flying is terrible, clunky, slow and there is literally nothing in space. Nothing.

Like exploring planets? The planets are smaller than your backyard, and there is nothing on a planet. Nothing.

Like shooting? Worst shooting gameplay ever, there's Doom clones from 1995 that are better, and I'm not joking, it's straight up the worst ♥♥♥♥ ever.

Like managing a ship? There's a couple on/off switches and that't about it, it might give you the impression that the panels are complex, but they're not, they just look cool on face value but once you get in the game there's like 3 buttons you can click and trust me when I say that after pressing them twice you don't feel like repeating it.

This game is extremely shallow and overpriced. Don't buy this unless it's 3 dollars/euros. This should have been a free game, and I hope more negative reviews roll in because frankly I'm appalled at how all these 3 hours game time reviewers are giving good reviews for absolutely one of the most boring games.

You're warned, this game is absolutely not worth money, it should be free for the hobby project it really is. Disgusting greedy kid who charges for this. Go home. Take my money and donate it to some charity because you have no shame or dignity for charging people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a POS.  I can't believe I wasted $25 on it.  Yeah, I know it's an early access game and that comes with some issues, but everything about this game is bad.  Cool premise -- I've been looking for a good space co-op game for a while, but this isn't it.  The graphics look like a late '90s game.  The controls are clunky.  You get dropped into the game with no explanation of how to play, and no instructions.

Again I've been looking for a game just like this for a while, but nothing about it is enjoyable.  Maybe if better programmers were building it, or if it was farther along.  But don't waste your money.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIncredibly simple and not worth the cost. Gameplay consists of very few and basic mechanics. Cooperation with friends is fun, but you quickly realize that there is no real progression and that you're stuck doing the same basic maneuvers over and over. There's only so many times I can jump and pilot around while my friend fires lazers. In the end, it just leaves you wishing you hadn't spent your cash. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent 23 mins runing around my ship which I emersly enjoyed but this game has me at 50/50 on like and dislike and heres why.

Like.
the graphics are fairly good and not in your face nor so tacky and the size of the ship can keep you exploring and enjoying the surroundings as I went for the Stealth transport ship.
There is a lot of detail in the creature comforts in the games ship and I can get to see my own feet hehe that is a happy moment from me hehe I know im strange.

Dislike.
This game has been made to force you to play with 4 other players and NOT even have the option to have NPC crew to fill in on the roles of the crew you dont have any real life players to fill in and this means YOU CANT even get to play let alone do ANYTHING other than run around your ship or fly it in a not very good flight screen view and the flight controles of the ship is lousy to say the least.

If you dont have 4 friends with this game then id advise to not bother with this game but if you do happen to have 4 friends with this game then its a must buy.
Im not being biest in any way shape or form im just being hounest and as time goes by and I get more feel of this game my RATE for this game will chop and change.
I just hope the devs really do pay attention to the players as without them then the game is as good as a shopping mall with no filled shops.

For the time being this is getting a thumbs down from myself.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLike most early access games, this game shows a lot of potential.  They nailed on the head the fun part of cooperative and exploration games.  This game really forces you and your crew to work together to fight off hostile ships, or explore planets.  Unfortunately, that's pretty much all the game has to do.  There's a complex galaxy full of countless planets and systems, and each of them is one of 3 things, a planet to loot and maybe shoot something, a mostly empty sector to shoot down an enemy ship, or a trade station.  I would say if this game is on sale for a few bucks, pick it up for you and some friends and enjoy yourself for a few hours, but after those few hours, you'll probably have seen most of what the game has to offer currently.  Once they begin to add some more diverse content to the game regularly, then I would recommend this game for full price.

Well as a person who loves a good space game, mp adds to the flavour, Pulsar is one that deserves more attention and players.

The graphics as stated by others are not High Def HD, nor are they spectacular in any way but the game play makes that a non issue.  It reminds me of the dated graphics in Sword of The Stars 1, {They haave been greatly surpassed but it is hard to find a game that has such robust networking(lan) capability and detailed gameplay for something so old}.

Pulsar is a lot of fun to play. We play it on a lan in one house with some friends who join the crew online.  So far we have had no crashes or loss of connection due to the game.  We continue to discover new things as we explore and sometimes die in our ship.

On our last mission to find a lost station crew we entered caves to kill spider like critters that could burrow up from the sand and rock and kill us.

Then while exploring I climbed the rocky mountain ridge around the base and discovered something even more amazing.  I can't say if it was designed to be a barrier to the area but once at the top of the ridge, clouds of dust formed like whirlwinds and then some enormous creature came up from below out of the rock and ate us!!

We barely saw portions of the beast poke up through rock as we died.  I kind of wish the death took a little longer so we could see more of the creature!!

I think if we get to go back to that planet i will try and do a video capture and put a red shirt" crew member in harms way while I capture the critter eating him!!

It reminded me of the great worms from Dune.

If you like adventure
recommended:
exploring and get better but not always having an easy time of it out in unknown space then buy this game.

It can only get better.

The only caveat is until the bots get better you really need 2 or 3 humans to run the ship for battles and exploring or you will find it very tough to progress right now but It is still well worth buying."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually write game reviews, but I think this deserves one and I believe in supporting this project.

The essence of the game is fairly straight forward, you and four others, man the ship (Unless you're a feminist, in which case you operate it)
What really stands out with this game is that you each perform a specific role. Pilot, Gunner, Scientist, Engineer and Captain. Each role requires a certain degree of competence, co-oporation and communiucation (The three big C's essentiually) Without these, you're pretty much doomed.

So you operate your ship performing your designated role. I won't go into detail about the roles because ♥♥♥♥ that. You jump from sector to sector in a procedural map which, with every jump and action performed, can change in regards to political alignment. Therefore a friendly sector may invariably be hostile as you're playing.

One thing which really does stand out with this game really is the ship to ship battles. The standard set up is you fire weapons at each other and hope they die and you live. Pretty standard. However, there's so much more going on than that. Your scientist is busy keeping you afloat uploading shield boosters, while sending ship crippling computer viruses to the enemy ship (if your ship so has) and protecting your own from hostile ones. The engineer is dashing around keeping your power levels sustainable and preventing the core from exploding. All the while the pilot is trying to get you the hell out of there if you're outmatched.
While this is happening,, you've got the possibility for the opposing ships crew to teleport onto your ship. You're not safe on your comfortable ship. In return, you can board the enemy ship and with skill you can claim it for your own, these ships generally being better than the starting ships.

There's a lot to this game that I just can't be bothered to detail, but suffice to say it's got great potential. With any luck the devs will continue to support, develop and grow this game whereas too many early access games don't get anywhere near enough development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've played Faster Than Light (FTL), then you MAY enjoy PULSAR.
This game should be played with at least one or two other people.  You start off picking a ship.  After that the host (I think) has to choose Captain out of the 5 classes.  The captain can bring up the map, chart a course through the large and extensive universe.  The ship itself has shields, which protect the hull until the shields take enough damage for the enemy ships to deal damage to your hull, which once the hull reaches zero, your ship explodes and either you reload, or start a new ship.  Each class has a station, or their own in-game computer screen that you stand at.  There are many rooms in the ship, and each of the ship's systems are connected to the 4 main systems.  Science, Engineering, Weapons, Life Support.  Those are the 4 systems you must protect.  If they get damaged enough, a fire starts in the room that you have to put out with extinguishers, then repair the system before the fire starts again.
There are missions that you can complete which give you credits and fame.  I spend the credits on replacing ship systems with better ones from repair stations located sparingly throughout the solar system.
There are factions.  The infested I have never had the pleasure of meeting but I have heard of them.  Some sort of alien race that create organic or living ships.  There are other neutral or hostile factions I have either not met or have had nothing to do with as of yet.  If you play with a group of friends, you WILL have fun with this game.  Play alone, and it gets rather boring.  The UI could use some work, and more game content would be welcome.  Controller support needs to improve, which it has, but I feel like more customization should be had.  I tried using all the buttons on my xbox 360 controller and I was unable to use the bumpers, which isn't that big a deal.  I play the game mostly with mouse and keyboard unless I'm flying the ship.
I would rate this game 9/10.  It's in BETA now so when they fully finish this game, it will be awesome - and it's already really fun.  They plan to come out with much more, such as crafting items and more talents for each class.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr - This is one of those games that highly relies on -who- you play with. If you have a good group of gaming buddies it will be a blast.

I can remember getting the Ebon Hawk in KOTOR and enjoyed owning a spaceship. In FTL I was jealous of the little crew members I got to move around because they were actually playing in the ship. This game in my opinion has really given gamers what they want. You get to be a crew member on a ship and perform a role to help the team meet their goals.

What really makes it a great game is who you play with. So imagine this game more as a foundation for good fun. Clashing personalities, misunderstandings, and chaos are things you will talk about for months after playing a session.

Expect to see scenes like this:

Engineer - guys I'm really tired.
Captain - ok dropping us out of warp now.
Pilot - crap, we have like three phase drones right on top of us.
Captain - ok everyone we are going to warp out, pilot start aligning, engineer initiate warp charge.
Engineer - Copa! Copacabana!
Captain - Engineer where are those engines?
Engineer - The hottest spot north of Havana!
Science - shields down Captain!
Captain - Science go to engineering and start the warp!
Pilot - too late!
Captain - Ahhhhh!
Science - Ahhhhh!
Engineer - At the copa Copacabana!
*boom*

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Anyone who is a fan of Co-op games as well as Sci-fi tv series like Firefly or Star Trek along with roguelike games like FTL: Faster than light should have a long look at picking up Pulsar:The Lost Colony. Heavily in beta after their successful kickstarter the game is coming together with updates every month or so.

As it stands at the time of writing, the game has very limited content, although the core game is solidly in place. A crew of five work together as they travel the galaxy making credits by destroying enemy starships, running missions and collecting scrap which in turn allows them to keep exploring the impressively huge map and keep their own starship upgraded.

The interactions between the players are the main selling point of the game and like the crew of the Enterprise or Serenity each member relies on the others for their own success and enjoyment, to a point. While it is entirely possible to play the game solo or with 2-3 good crew members the real fun comes from 5 members with mics who are able to smoothly interact and keep their ship running.

A typical gaming session would follow a fairly similar path. The captain chooses the ships destination, the engineer charges the warp core and can allocate power to the science and engineering sections to speed up this process. Once charged the word can be given to jump the ship into warp. After a few minutes of travel time (which can be handily skipped) the ship exits and the players will usually be greeted with an expansive sector littered with asteroids or space debris, a planetary system or trade outpost.  More often than not an enemy will be present and the captain can give the word to engage. The ship can also be keep in silent running with systems powered down in the hope to pass through undetected or use a computer virus to siphon the enemy ship of credits before jumping away silently.

While the weapons specialist fires from the main turret the pilot must keep the ship in firing range and within the turrets arc of fire.
The science officer uses his station to disable the enemy's shields and thrusters and can buff his own ship with shield recharges and speed boosts all the while scanning the enemy and relaying any useful information back to the crew. Further more he can alter the shield frequencies for added damage reduction and detect any components that might warrant boarding the enemy ship and stripping it for parts.
With all this action taking place the ships main reactor is placed under huge stress causing heat to build up and it's up to the engineer deep in the bowls of the ship (or from the bridge) to regulate which systems deserve more or less power, failure on his part could lead to a devastating core meltdown although that too can be handled with the right amount of teamwork.

Once the battle is over any scrap and parts can be collected, credits added to the ship's wallet and it's off to the next target or station to repair and look for upgrades.

It's this part of the game that is solid and although there is more content in the form of missions, planetary exploration and boss fights anyone buying the game in it's current state shouldn't look too far in front of what I've outlined.

I'm eager to see where the developers take the game and with more content being added frequently I'd highly recommend picking it up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is could be one of the greats once it's done. The star-ship control part of the game is extremely good; the away-team part less so. It lacks content (missions) as of beta 3 and this makes the game feel aimless (I'm not sure what to do). Content is to be added in the last phase of the game's development though. I'm looking forward to it.

Pros:
* Star-ship control part of the game is very good. it has good balance for each of the roles and is very engaging.
* I love the combination of first-person perspective and star-ship managment. It makes the game far more engaging than a  remote, third-person type of game.

Cons:
* Lacks content as of beta 3. This is the last phase of the game's development though and is to be expected.
* No local-only (LAN) gaming. This is planned for a later release though.
* The away-team part of the game is ok but I find fighting aliens on planets to be repetitive and not greatly exciting. I would to need to use more strategy to stay alive (like ducking or using terrain to provide cover). I would also like to see larger planets to explore; some of them feel somewhat cramped.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a BETA game, EA game but do not let that fool you. The game seems a little bit like Garrys Mod with all its quirks, but it has potential to be a solid game if it is done correctly and expands further out.

*BUY IT WITH FRIENDS* - You will need friends for this, the AI on it just ain't that good, but if you get a full crew then this game is pretty much FTL: Faster than Light in FPS mode. Going on planets is cool, the interplanetary fights are cool, the jump system is cool and there is a role for every person to worry about.

It has potential to be great, but even now it's worth putting a couple of hours into with friends. There's going to be a 4-5 pack soon I believe, so hold off if you're starved on money. Definetly one to watch though.

Also you cannot build your own ship you just upgrade one of the starting ships. Other then those small things it is for sure worth getting at least on a sale price. I think $25 is a bit high when there is not quite enough content to justify spending $25 on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tried quite a few early access games looking for something a little bit different to the tonne of half finished zombie survival games that are being dumped on us right now and with this little gem i think I've found something i can get stuck into.
Don't try and play solo, doing that will very quickly becoming frustrating as you rely on the AI bots to do things that they (as yet) cannot do, this means running about like a lunatic trying to micro manage your ship and you will quit before giving the game a chance to shine at what it does brilliantly, co-op play.

Jump into a game with either friends or randoms and you'll soon be fighting your way across the cosmos looking for that bigger gun, better engine, stronger shield, cheap nuke etc etc.

The core of the game is mostly finished and while there are still some minor bugs there is nothing that is game breaking that I've found, the devs have started to flesh out the universe now and bring more content to the different classes so very soon there will be more places to go and more things to do when you get there.

The games when I've logged in and joined random groups have been fun as well with everyone getting into their assigned characters and roleplaying with the rest of the group. Plus the advice i was given helped me with my own games playing with my brothers.

Will recommend this game and keep up the good work devs :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fantastic.  It boldly goes where no game has gone before: it places you in a crew of 5 other players each having their own responsibilities and when the crew works together you can accomplish almost anything.   That gives you a great sense of achievement both technically and socially that I haven't seen in any other game.

Communication is key so if your the silent type, it's probably not for you.  You HAVE to be engaged with your crew because the ships you crew simply won't function well without it.

The payoff is huge, you really feel like a member of a starship.  Another fantastic element is roleplay and gameplay are one and the same.  Your captain is your leader and speaking to him in true roleplay talk or just plain talk really makes no difference because it's really all the same thing.

There's a lot to learn in this game, but not overwhelming.  There's even a manual in the options menu if you need to read up on something.  Most of the game revolves around hanging with your crew as you visit planets and do away missions or space battles where you must fill a role whether it be piloting, managing the power systems, scanning for lifeforms, manning a turret, or what not.

Graphics as some have said, are not best of the best, but hardly bad actually I think they are very, very nice with plenty of fancy surface and lighting details.

The music has nothing on games like FTL, but again it is very good for it's purpose, and I suspect they will expand the soundtrack a lot more in the future.

The community is mostly great.  There are some greifers here and there, I find it's best to say hello when you join is a good way to know what kind of people you are going to play with.

It is still early access, but the devs are very active so lots of content pours in frequently.

Being EA, the planets you can visit are a bit limited in that you will find yourself visiting the same areas frequently until they add more locations.  However the galaxy map is huge and generated new in every new game and some things such as loot and enemies and backgrounds are generated differently with each planet, plus there's no limit to how many new planets the devs can create.  There's really no limit to the vast amount of possibilities this game has going for it.

The community is a bit small right now but there's never a shortage of games you can find to join, just make sure to warm up to the captain for best results. (He is the only one that can kick players)

Price is a bit high for EA, but it is a fully multiplayer game and the base game is already very solid.

Overall this game is really the experience I've been looking for for a long time: a game where you team up as a crew of players and have endless adventures aboard a totally huge randomly generated galaxy.

8.9/10 EA score,  10/10 if they get everything right in the official release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review is written during beta 4.2 NOV 2015

Pros: Has classic space combat mechanics; Your weapons fire when the angle is appropriate and is charged and you have one shield that covers the entire ship. You also have a quantum shield that prevents the enemy from teleporting to your ship. The player(s) have to manage the energy distribution, control the amount of heat in the reactor to prevent a system failure, and use programs to debuff the enemy or remove debuffs.

Cons: Default Unity shaders. Lacks quest; Classic fetch quest. Limited variety of firearms, they are all pistols. Limited vareity of components, each component has only 0-5 variants with only the level scaling up. Limited amount of opponents; You get to fight 5 special enemy ships and then the default ships. The AI is just godly stupid, it cannot tell when there is a wall between them and will try to shoot through walls. Everytime you load a gamesave, you have to respend your talent points and AI priority. Invisible items that show up on radar but you cannot see; And yes, I'm on the right floor. Alot of the planets just use the same map. Apparently, every ship uses the same computer architecture because viruses work on all of them; Even the infected.

I wanted to stay neutral but Steam made me choose.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well as a person who loves a good space game, mp adds to the flavour, Pulsar is one that deserves more attention and players.

The graphics as stated by others are not High Def HD, nor are they spectacular in any way but the game play makes that a non issue.  It reminds me of the dated graphics in Sword of The Stars 1, {They haave been greatly surpassed but it is hard to find a game that has such robust networking(lan) capability and detailed gameplay for something so old}.

Pulsar is a lot of fun to play. We play it on a lan in one house with some friends who join the crew online.  So far we have had no crashes or loss of connection due to the game.  We continue to discover new things as we explore and sometimes die in our ship.

On our last mission to find a lost station crew we entered caves to kill spider like critters that could burrow up from the sand and rock and kill us.

Then while exploring I climbed the rocky mountain ridge around the base and discovered something even more amazing.  I can't say if it was designed to be a barrier to the area but once at the top of the ridge, clouds of dust formed like whirlwinds and then some enormous creature came up from below out of the rock and ate us!!

We barely saw portions of the beast poke up through rock as we died.  I kind of wish the death took a little longer so we could see more of the creature!!

I think if we get to go back to that planet i will try and do a video capture and put a red shirt" crew member in harms way while I capture the critter eating him!!

It reminded me of the great worms from Dune.

If you like adventure
recommended:
exploring and get better but not always having an easy time of it out in unknown space then buy this game.

It can only get better.

The only caveat is until the bots get better you really need 2 or 3 humans to run the ship for battles and exploring or you will find it very tough to progress right now but It is still well worth buying."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually write game reviews, but I think this deserves one and I believe in supporting this project.

The essence of the game is fairly straight forward, you and four others, man the ship (Unless you're a feminist, in which case you operate it)
What really stands out with this game is that you each perform a specific role. Pilot, Gunner, Scientist, Engineer and Captain. Each role requires a certain degree of competence, co-oporation and communiucation (The three big C's essentiually) Without these, you're pretty much doomed.

So you operate your ship performing your designated role. I won't go into detail about the roles because ♥♥♥♥ that. You jump from sector to sector in a procedural map which, with every jump and action performed, can change in regards to political alignment. Therefore a friendly sector may invariably be hostile as you're playing.

One thing which really does stand out with this game really is the ship to ship battles. The standard set up is you fire weapons at each other and hope they die and you live. Pretty standard. However, there's so much more going on than that. Your scientist is busy keeping you afloat uploading shield boosters, while sending ship crippling computer viruses to the enemy ship (if your ship so has) and protecting your own from hostile ones. The engineer is dashing around keeping your power levels sustainable and preventing the core from exploding. All the while the pilot is trying to get you the hell out of there if you're outmatched.
While this is happening,, you've got the possibility for the opposing ships crew to teleport onto your ship. You're not safe on your comfortable ship. In return, you can board the enemy ship and with skill you can claim it for your own, these ships generally being better than the starting ships.

There's a lot to this game that I just can't be bothered to detail, but suffice to say it's got great potential. With any luck the devs will continue to support, develop and grow this game whereas too many early access games don't get anywhere near enough development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING: If your ready to have to put up with role-play captains who won't let you use a fire extinguisher for no reason other than it doesn't fit roleplay, captains who if you give any kind of order to anyone they will jump on you and tell you that's not your job, captains that don't like it when you make the tiniest of mistakes, or captains who will ask you if you have teamspeak and if you say no they just kick you, get this game. If can't handle that, don't buy this game.

If you've played Guns of Icarus Online, this game is pretty similar.

You and 1-4 other players (along with bots) pilot a space ship, there are 5 classes and each has a unique role and do uniqe jobs. Heavy teamwork is required in order to succeed. You'll go around the universe destroying other space ships, exploring ruins, and pillaging planets. All of this is very, very fun, which is why I recommend this game.

As said the only downside is the role-play/super serious sub-community that is quite idiotic and can't accept the fact that what they're playing doesn't affect them in real life by much at all...

Pros:
+Fun game
+Team-based
+Mature community
+Lots of potential
+Unique
+Great design
+Amazing space asethetics

Cons:
-Role-play/serious sub-community
-Bad NPCs
-Easy to grief
-No tutorial
-Not much planet depth

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr - This is one of those games that highly relies on -who- you play with. If you have a good group of gaming buddies it will be a blast.

I can remember getting the Ebon Hawk in KOTOR and enjoyed owning a spaceship. In FTL I was jealous of the little crew members I got to move around because they were actually playing in the ship. This game in my opinion has really given gamers what they want. You get to be a crew member on a ship and perform a role to help the team meet their goals.

What really makes it a great game is who you play with. So imagine this game more as a foundation for good fun. Clashing personalities, misunderstandings, and chaos are things you will talk about for months after playing a session.

Expect to see scenes like this:

Engineer - guys I'm really tired.
Captain - ok dropping us out of warp now.
Pilot - crap, we have like three phase drones right on top of us.
Captain - ok everyone we are going to warp out, pilot start aligning, engineer initiate warp charge.
Engineer - Copa! Copacabana!
Captain - Engineer where are those engines?
Engineer - The hottest spot north of Havana!
Science - shields down Captain!
Captain - Science go to engineering and start the warp!
Pilot - too late!
Captain - Ahhhhh!
Science - Ahhhhh!
Engineer - At the copa Copacabana!
*boom*

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've played Faster Than Light (FTL), then you MAY enjoy PULSAR.
This game should be played with at least one or two other people.  You start off picking a ship.  After that the host (I think) has to choose Captain out of the 5 classes.  The captain can bring up the map, chart a course through the large and extensive universe.  The ship itself has shields, which protect the hull until the shields take enough damage for the enemy ships to deal damage to your hull, which once the hull reaches zero, your ship explodes and either you reload, or start a new ship.  Each class has a station, or their own in-game computer screen that you stand at.  There are many rooms in the ship, and each of the ship's systems are connected to the 4 main systems.  Science, Engineering, Weapons, Life Support.  Those are the 4 systems you must protect.  If they get damaged enough, a fire starts in the room that you have to put out with extinguishers, then repair the system before the fire starts again.
There are missions that you can complete which give you credits and fame.  I spend the credits on replacing ship systems with better ones from repair stations located sparingly throughout the solar system.
There are factions.  The infested I have never had the pleasure of meeting but I have heard of them.  Some sort of alien race that create organic or living ships.  There are other neutral or hostile factions I have either not met or have had nothing to do with as of yet.  If you play with a group of friends, you WILL have fun with this game.  Play alone, and it gets rather boring.  The UI could use some work, and more game content would be welcome.  Controller support needs to improve, which it has, but I feel like more customization should be had.  I tried using all the buttons on my xbox 360 controller and I was unable to use the bumpers, which isn't that big a deal.  I play the game mostly with mouse and keyboard unless I'm flying the ship.
I would rate this game 9/10.  It's in BETA now so when they fully finish this game, it will be awesome - and it's already really fun.  They plan to come out with much more, such as crafting items and more talents for each class.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This title has easily become one of my favorites I've played in a while. I and 4 of my friends get to man and operate an entire spaceship? Warp to unknown star systems and explore planets? This is phenomenal. I feel like I'm playing FTL in first person, with 4 of my friends. The game has a bit of a learning curve, but it's role based, so you really need reliable crew members. Lots of trial and error. I think the farthest we've gotten was 8 jumps, but our Chaos level was maxed at 6. We were under the impression everything in space was hostile, so we immediately fired on anything. We've read a bit about the Chaos levels, and we've now managed to stay hidden from enemy sensors and we're getting a more accurate read on hostile" entities.

If Hard Science Fiction is your thing

With the right friends, this game really does seem like your own personal episode of Firefly or Star Trek.
So, here's my take on this game.

The Captain ordered us to look for security drones.  We spent about 30 minutes on a search and destroy until we needed to head back and repair the hull.  I am the pilot and yes, I'm a girl.  My first attempt at docking with the repair station was ...sporty.  If you've ever seen the movie galaxy quest then you will have a good idea of what it's like to fit the destroyer into a repair station docking bay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Years ago I dreamed up a nice little concept for a game. A difficult co-op sci-fi FTL-like FPS. Fast forward a while and this game pops out of nowhere. I played the game on my own with bots and had a fun time, but I was waiting to write a review until I'd played the multiplayer with friends, since the game IS all about cooperation and teamwork and that bullocks.
When I eventually did play with a friend, we had so much fun getting blown up or turned into swiss cheese by enemy crews. What's even better is that that was before we even discovered you could explore planets!

-PROS-
-A completely cooperative game, no competitive modes. This might be a con for some people, I don't mind it though.
-A vast, dangerous galaxy to explore with six different factions (Not including the Infection)
-Missions, albeit not randomly generated ones, that can sometimes end up being more of an adventure than you originally expected.
-Procedurally generated planets with different hazards, such as an acidic atmosphere, or a lack of oxygen.
-Multiple ships to choose from with different interiors, layouts, and specs.

-CONS-
-The planets are sometimes disappointingly small, and can be glitchy. It IS early access however, so what did you expect?
-It isn't exactly overflowing with content. It is still VERY entertaining, even if you're only playing with one other person, so it makes up for it.
-While I don't mind the clean, almost cell shaded look of the equipment and ships-- Infact I think some of the planets I've seen have even made me go That's really pretty!"-- But the people look hideous. They're like tall
recommended: I'd recommend this game if you have friends
hoursPlayed: and even if you don't. You're missing out if you don't at least play on a public game. Careful though

I have been playing this game since the very first day it came out on Alpha, and I love it. It is amazing to see how far it has come since day one. The game is beautiful, fun and immersive. While it can be a little daunting to get into, it is well worth it. The developers are committed to listening to the comminity and their passion for the game really shows through. At those terrifying moments when alarms are sounding, reactors are failing and hull integrity is dropping, it really feels like you're there in the moment, fighting hard with your crew exploring the galaxy.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll fully admit that it took me a while to decide if I was going to purchase this title or not. The graphics in the screen shots and the videos made me wary that this was yet another Early Access title that does the same thing that other, bigger, prettier games do so much better. (And lets be honest, if you've played Early Access you probably know exactly what I mean.)

Then, I decided that I would go on YouTube (something I never do) in order to see what the game play was actually like. What I saw intrigued me enough that I actually bought an Early Access title for what I thought was a lot of money for such a simple looking game.

So far, I'm pretty amazed by what Leafy Games has managed to put together. After you play this, you'll wonder why it took so long for a game company to see space combat through a cooperative lens.

The game isn't done yet, don't get me wrong, but what it does is something that no other game has really attempted with any degree of success. It takes the somewhat tried-and-true formula of a space sim/roguelike/shooter/RPG and instead of giving each player their own unique starship they make you cooperate to run that one starship well.

The five classes they have in the game are mostly well balanced around one another, as each class 'controls' a particular section of the ship. Some roles, like Engineer, involve pushing buttons and pulling levers to keep the ship from overheating and providing power for the other roles to use. Science is the eyes and ears of the ship while providing offensive and defensive buffs through power allocated by the Engineer. The pilot flies the ship and collects space-loot while ensuring that they follow the captains flight plan. There's a lot there, and while it might be confusing your first game nothing is so complex that it will take more than a half-hour to learn it. (Also, the user manual is surprisingly useful for a first-time player that prefers not to engage in trial-by-fire.)

The community thus far have been very helpful and nice, which is also a refreshing change of pace, although there are the obligatory trolls/children that will join into your game to shut off oxygen to your ship or purposefully start fires/destroy subsystems for the sheer hate of it. So far, they're relatively few and it's generally pretty easy to recover from any of their hijinks. It's also a small community, so after a while you'll probably know enough people to steer clear of any jokers you might encounter.

Obviously, the game is growing, and really my only critique is that there needs to be a few more things that the Captain can override as far as crew decisions that could be deemed 'griefing', such as firing off nuclear warheads or turning off shields mid-combat.

The game play is as fast or as slow as your group can handle. Planets are relatively relaxing without any real threat of losing anything, death is painless as you have infinite clones (Although in hardcore mode you don't get a save at all, so you better not all die at once or it's game over.), and voice chat is almost a must if you really get into this game. Bad decisions are punished hard and fast, often times without you necessarily knowing what went wrong. (Such as shooting at a -much- more powerful ship than your own, only to be one-shot in return because Science didn't bother to scan the enemy ship to determine it's relative strength.) You won't blow up out of nowhere due to any one crew members mistakes though, so don't concern yourself with the engineer accidentally ejecting the warp core or hitting the wrong button and killing everyone instantly.

Most games that label themselves as 'cooperative' are anything but cooperative. This game is a breath of fresh air into the space sim genre and I hope Leafy follows through on this concept and continues their track record of timely updates and great ideas.

As my last parting thought, if you're at all a fan of Star Trek and always wished there was a game that finally scratched that itch that nothing seems to satisfy, this game is literally tailor made for you. Even if you -don't- like Star Trek, this game is worth a look and a purchase just for the innovation they've already put out into the gaming universe.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Anyone who is a fan of Co-op games as well as Sci-fi tv series like Firefly or Star Trek along with roguelike games like FTL: Faster than light should have a long look at picking up Pulsar:The Lost Colony. Heavily in beta after their successful kickstarter the game is coming together with updates every month or so.

As it stands at the time of writing, the game has very limited content, although the core game is solidly in place. A crew of five work together as they travel the galaxy making credits by destroying enemy starships, running missions and collecting scrap which in turn allows them to keep exploring the impressively huge map and keep their own starship upgraded.

The interactions between the players are the main selling point of the game and like the crew of the Enterprise or Serenity each member relies on the others for their own success and enjoyment, to a point. While it is entirely possible to play the game solo or with 2-3 good crew members the real fun comes from 5 members with mics who are able to smoothly interact and keep their ship running.

A typical gaming session would follow a fairly similar path. The captain chooses the ships destination, the engineer charges the warp core and can allocate power to the science and engineering sections to speed up this process. Once charged the word can be given to jump the ship into warp. After a few minutes of travel time (which can be handily skipped) the ship exits and the players will usually be greeted with an expansive sector littered with asteroids or space debris, a planetary system or trade outpost.  More often than not an enemy will be present and the captain can give the word to engage. The ship can also be keep in silent running with systems powered down in the hope to pass through undetected or use a computer virus to siphon the enemy ship of credits before jumping away silently.

While the weapons specialist fires from the main turret the pilot must keep the ship in firing range and within the turrets arc of fire.
The science officer uses his station to disable the enemy's shields and thrusters and can buff his own ship with shield recharges and speed boosts all the while scanning the enemy and relaying any useful information back to the crew. Further more he can alter the shield frequencies for added damage reduction and detect any components that might warrant boarding the enemy ship and stripping it for parts.
With all this action taking place the ships main reactor is placed under huge stress causing heat to build up and it's up to the engineer deep in the bowls of the ship (or from the bridge) to regulate which systems deserve more or less power, failure on his part could lead to a devastating core meltdown although that too can be handled with the right amount of teamwork.

Once the battle is over any scrap and parts can be collected, credits added to the ship's wallet and it's off to the next target or station to repair and look for upgrades.

It's this part of the game that is solid and although there is more content in the form of missions, planetary exploration and boss fights anyone buying the game in it's current state shouldn't look too far in front of what I've outlined.

I'm eager to see where the developers take the game and with more content being added frequently I'd highly recommend picking it up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fantastic game! I love it so much and I have played like 20 hours in two weeks. Great game, but only if you have friends or people to play with as you need to be talking to them through a mic and stuff, (teamspeak or skype), preferably teamspeak.

The main aspect of the game is teamwork as if you aren't communicating and people are doing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, then you will just continuously die. There is a game manual which the captain in your crew should read. I got my friends to buy it and we have a crew of 4 people, (the pilot is a bot). It also works with 2 people as you can just have the captain and engineer. This means Captain does science stuff and their normal stuff, and Engineer does weapons stuff and their normal stuff. This works with almost any combination.


So many planets to explore, parts to buy, quests to get and complete. Overall, an amazingly well built game and I recommend it to anyone who has people to play it with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've downloaded this game first via some strange ways (also know as not-very-legal-versions). I wanted to try before buy, because I've problems with horror/suspense games (I was afraid this game was, but isn't not!).

Imagine Star Trek, without the Hollywood things. This is PULSAR. You can control your own ship, have friends or meet someone to help with your ship, land in planets to explore or complete missions (now you can research things from items you find in the planet).

PROS:
- The game is really fun.
- The graphic is not heavy but it's cool.
- The game dynamic is amazing, a lot of things to do, etc.
- Is a randomly-generated universe.
- A lot of people are noobie-friendly. Is not like the majority of multiplayer games who don't care about the newbies. I like it, since I'm always a newbie!

CONS:
- A mini-map inside a ship, like the carrier, will be great (really - it's huge and I usually get lost).
- It's in beta, so: bugs.
- There is a little big of lag.
- It would be great to have more team in the ship (up to 10 probably? Specially for ships with more than 1 gun).
- Some ships are extremely DARK.
- Some people are bad and will damage your ship just because they can and nobody will know who the person was, except if caught in the act. A log system for the captain will be great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr - This is one of those games that highly relies on -who- you play with. If you have a good group of gaming buddies it will be a blast.

I can remember getting the Ebon Hawk in KOTOR and enjoyed owning a spaceship. In FTL I was jealous of the little crew members I got to move around because they were actually playing in the ship. This game in my opinion has really given gamers what they want. You get to be a crew member on a ship and perform a role to help the team meet their goals.

What really makes it a great game is who you play with. So imagine this game more as a foundation for good fun. Clashing personalities, misunderstandings, and chaos are things you will talk about for months after playing a session.

Expect to see scenes like this:

Engineer - guys I'm really tired.
Captain - ok dropping us out of warp now.
Pilot - crap, we have like three phase drones right on top of us.
Captain - ok everyone we are going to warp out, pilot start aligning, engineer initiate warp charge.
Engineer - Copa! Copacabana!
Captain - Engineer where are those engines?
Engineer - The hottest spot north of Havana!
Science - shields down Captain!
Captain - Science go to engineering and start the warp!
Pilot - too late!
Captain - Ahhhhh!
Science - Ahhhhh!
Engineer - At the copa Copacabana!
*boom*

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've played Faster Than Light (FTL), then you MAY enjoy PULSAR.
This game should be played with at least one or two other people.  You start off picking a ship.  After that the host (I think) has to choose Captain out of the 5 classes.  The captain can bring up the map, chart a course through the large and extensive universe.  The ship itself has shields, which protect the hull until the shields take enough damage for the enemy ships to deal damage to your hull, which once the hull reaches zero, your ship explodes and either you reload, or start a new ship.  Each class has a station, or their own in-game computer screen that you stand at.  There are many rooms in the ship, and each of the ship's systems are connected to the 4 main systems.  Science, Engineering, Weapons, Life Support.  Those are the 4 systems you must protect.  If they get damaged enough, a fire starts in the room that you have to put out with extinguishers, then repair the system before the fire starts again.
There are missions that you can complete which give you credits and fame.  I spend the credits on replacing ship systems with better ones from repair stations located sparingly throughout the solar system.
There are factions.  The infested I have never had the pleasure of meeting but I have heard of them.  Some sort of alien race that create organic or living ships.  There are other neutral or hostile factions I have either not met or have had nothing to do with as of yet.  If you play with a group of friends, you WILL have fun with this game.  Play alone, and it gets rather boring.  The UI could use some work, and more game content would be welcome.  Controller support needs to improve, which it has, but I feel like more customization should be had.  I tried using all the buttons on my xbox 360 controller and I was unable to use the bumpers, which isn't that big a deal.  I play the game mostly with mouse and keyboard unless I'm flying the ship.
I would rate this game 9/10.  It's in BETA now so when they fully finish this game, it will be awesome - and it's already really fun.  They plan to come out with much more, such as crafting items and more talents for each class.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game version 4.2

As it stands right now I really enjoy playing this game, mechanics are great and has a lot of potential, I look forward to updates.

Pros
Great ship to ship combat
Actual boarding action to capture ships
Can go to planet surfaces
Good feel of team game play
Can walk around ship and has sub systems

Cons
Limited way to make money
Lacking in system diversity and persistent (meaning objects despawn after leaving the system)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you're into Star Trek and have some friends who also like Star Trek this game is amazing. I don't recommend for single-player, just because there's a lot of multitasking and multiple stations that need to be manned by someone other than a manually programmed NPC. But it has a good community, and you can pretty much play with just two people. Lots of places to explore and difficult ships/missions to take on. If you're looking for a new single-player space sim that has depth in story and crazy expansive dungeons this might not be for you. Clearly a game still in development. But still amazing.
